questions.text: A patient who needs surgery has a bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl and a serum creatinine level of 1.9 mg/dl. What is the preferred muscle relaxant for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Atracurium

Atracurium is metabolized by Hoffman’s Elimination which is non-enzymatic, non-organ dependent clearance.
Thus, it is the safest drug in liver and renal failure.
 

* [Extra Edge]: Hofmann elimination

  • This refers to inactivation of the drug in the body fluids by spon­taneous molecular rearrangement without the agency of any enzyme.
  • Atracurium’s disappearance from the body depends on hydrolysis of the ester moiety by plasma esterases and by a spontaneous or Hofmann degradation (cleavage of the N-alkyl portion in the benzylisoquinoline). Hence, two routes for termination of effect are available, both of which remain functional in renal failure.
* [Extra Edge]: Conditions and the muscle relaxants of choice 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 380.

questions.text: The statements concerning succinylcholine causing neuromuscular blockade are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Fade on tetanic stimulation

On tetanic stimulation, Sch undergoes post-tetanic potentiation instead of fade.
Succinyl choline is a depolarizing muscle relaxant. It has a TOF>0.4

* [Extra Edge]: Clinical assessment of neuromuscular block


FIG: TOF protocol
  • During partial competitive block (as occurs during onset and recovery or reversal) the degree of block corresponds to the decrease in TOF-ratio, because competitive blockers exhibit ‘fade’ phenomenon.
  • As the muscles recover, the TOF-ratio improves and becomes 1.0 at complete recovery.
  • Spontaneous breathing may be resumed when TOF-ratio recovers to > 0.7.
  • On the other hand, classical or phase-I depolarizing block does not exhibit fade; the TOF-ratio remains 1.0, though all the 4 twitches are depressed equally depending on the degree of block.
  • Fade is again seen when phase II or desensitization block occurs with prolonged use of a depolarizing agent and TOF-ratio is depressed as in the case of competitive block. However, SCh generally requires no monitoring.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 379.
Online Reference:
Xue L, Wu LG. Post-tetanic potentiation is caused by two signalling mechanisms affecting quantal size and quantal content. J Physiol. 2010 Dec 15;588(Pt 24):4987-94. doi: 10.1113/jphysiol.2010.196964. Epub 2010 Nov 1. PMID: 21041528; PMCID: PMC3036192.

questions.text: Select the position that best describes the location of celiac plexus.
questions.solution:

questions.text: What tendon travels beneath the sustentaculum tali?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Flexor Hallucis Longus The sustentaculum tali is a bony shelf-like structure located on the medial (inner) side of the calcaneus bone in the foot. The tendon that travels beneath the sustentaculum tali is the tendon of the flexor hallucis longus muscle. The flexor hallucis longus muscle is one of the deep muscles located in the posterior compartment of the leg. Its tendon passes behind the medial malleolus (bump on the inner side of the ankle) and then travels beneath the sustentaculum tali.

questions.text: Which of the options below traverses the magnum foramen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Vertebral artery The foramen magnum is a large opening at the base of the skull through which the spinal cord exits the skull and becomes the spinal canal. The vertebral artery is an important blood vessel that supplies the brain and spinal cord with oxygenated blood. The vertebral artery travels through the foramen magnum to enter the cranial cavity. Once inside the cranial cavity, the vertebral arteries join together to form the basilar artery, which is a critical part of the brain's blood supply.

Other options:-
  • Sympathetic chain and Internal carotid artery pass via Foramen Lacerum
  • CN 11 passes via Jugular Foramen

questions.solution:

questions.text: Collaterals may arise in post-ductal aortic coarctation by any of the following, with the exception of:

questions.text: The following is a crucial lung non-respiratory function of the lungs?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1. Anion balance.

The lungs play a crucial role in maintaining acid-base balance, which is related to anion balance. Specifically, the lungs help regulate the levels of bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) and carbon dioxide (CO₂) in the blood. Through the process of ventilation, the lungs help remove CO₂, which can combine with water to form carbonic acid. This indirectly affects the balance of anions like bicarbonate.

While other balances (sodium, potassium, calcium) are primarily managed by other organs like the kidneys, the lungs have a significant impact on maintaining anion balance, especially related to the bicarbonate buffer system in the blood

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 626,641

questions.text: Maximum water absorption in the digestive system happens in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Jejunum The GIT absorbs approximately 8L of fluid in a day out of which 2L is water. Maximum absorption occurs in the proximal small intestine because of the following reasons. Surface area: it has a large surface area for absorption due to its extensive folding, villi, and microvilli Length of transit: SI has a relatively long transit time, allowing sufficient contact time between the luminal contents and the absorptive surface Active transport of solutes: The active transport of solutes, such as sodium, across the intestinal epithelium creates an osmotic gradient. This gradient promotes the movement of water from the intestinal lumen into the epithelial cells Aquaporins: It is equipped with specialized water channels called aquaporins, which facilitate the rapid movement of water across the epithelial cells. While the small intestine is the primary site of water absorption, some water absorption also occurs in the large intestine (colon).

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 461

NO we all know it relaxes, VIP- Vaso-Inhibitory Peptide- as the name suggests it inhibits contraction thus causes relaxation.

questions.text: Abdominal spasm discomfort is reduced by using a hot water bottle via:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Stimulation of adrenergic fibers

Gate Control Theory of pain suggests that the spinal cord has a neurological 'gate' that controls pain signals to the brain. It asserts that non-painful input closes the nerve "gates" to painful input, which prevents pain sensation from traveling to the central nervous system
  • Visceral pain from the gastrointestinal tract is largely mediated by pain relaying ‘C’ fibers that run almost exclusively in the sympathetic (adrenergic) system
  • Heat impulses from hot water bottles are transmitted through larger A fibers and C fibers which have higher velocity
  • Relief of pain with a hot water bottle involves modulation of sympathetic pathways through stimulation of the ‘A’ and ‘C’ fibers thereby blocking the pain sensation carried by small ‘C’ fibers.

   


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 164

choices.text: Increase in the number of open capillaries

questions.text: During vigorous exercise, pulmonary arterial pressure barely rises but cardiac output (CO) increases up to fivefold. The best explanation for this physiological property of the pulmonary circulation is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Increase in the number of open capillaries During exercise the demand for O2 increases drastically. By opening more capillaries, the surface area available for gas exchange increases, allowing for a greater amount of oxygen to be taken up from the alveoli into the blood and a larger amount of carbon dioxide to be released from the blood into the alveoli for exhalation. Option 2 - Sympathetic activation can cause vasoconstriction in systemic circulation to redirect blood flow to the working muscles during exercise, but it does not play a significant role in regulating pulmonary vascular resistance. Option 3 – large amount of smooth muscles can constrict or dilate the arteries up to some extent but it’s not the primary mechanism. Option 4 – it is incorrect as the surface area for pulmonary circulation is actually very large.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 615,616

questions.text: The heart's phase of minimal motion during cardiac imaging is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Mid diastole

During mid diastole, the heart is in a relaxed state, and the ventricles are filling with blood. This phase is characterized by minimal motion of the heart, making it an optimal time for cardiac imaging procedures such as echocardiography or cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
 
  • Late systole (Option 1) refers to the end of the contraction phase of the cardiac cycle.
  • Mid systole (Option 2) is the middle of the contraction phase when the heart is actively pumping blood.
  • Late diastole (Option 3) refers to the end of the diastole phase just before the next contraction begins.



Reference: Otton, James M et al. “Defining the mid-diastolic imaging period for cardiac CT - lessons from tissue Doppler echocardiography.” BMC medical imaging vol. 13 5. 1 Feb. 2013, doi:10.1186/1471-2342-13-5. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3570333/

questions.text: Because fructan are not digested, they are employed as prebiotics just as inulin. Their resistance to digestion in upper GI tract is because of:
questions.solution:
Fructans are polysaccharides composed of fructose units, which can be linked together by β(2→1) or β(2→6) glycosidic bonds. The β-configuration refers to the orientation of the glycosidic bond relative to the plane of the sugar ring. In the β-configuration, the hydroxyl group attached to the anomeric carbon (C2 in fructose) is on the opposite side (axial position) of the ring relative to the CH2OH group at C6.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to find variations in gene expression and DNA sequence?
questions.solution:
Answer, option 4:- Microarray

- **Microarray** is a technique used to analyze and compare gene expression levels and variations in DNA sequences across thousands of genes simultaneously. It is commonly used to detect changes in mRNA expression (gene expression profiling) and identify mutations or single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in DNA.  

### Other Options:
1. **Northern Blot**: Used to detect RNA (mRNA) levels of a specific gene, indicating its expression.  
2. **Southern Blot**: Used to detect specific DNA sequences in a sample.  
3. **Western Blot**: Used to detect specific proteins in a sample.  

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 483.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is not utilised to identify a particular aneuploidy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) RT-PCR

FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization), QF-PCR (Quantitative Fluorescent Polymerase Chain Reaction), and Microarray are commonly used techniques for identifying specific aneuploidies.
RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a technique primarily used for detecting and quantifying gene expression levels, rather than identifying aneuploidies.
QF-PCR is Quality Fluorescence PCR and Microarray can detect aneuploidy though are mainly used to detect certain genomic defects frequently. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 181.

questions.text: The best method for prenatal haemophilia diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) PCR
 
  • PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is a commonly used method for detecting genetic mutations, including those associated with hemophilia.
  • Hemophilia: Hemophilia is a genetic bleeding disorder characterized by a deficiency or dysfunction of clotting factors, most commonly factor VIII (hemophilia A) or factor IX (hemophilia B).
  • This results in prolonged bleeding and impaired blood clotting.
  • Symptoms can range from mild to severe, with spontaneous bleeding into joints, muscles, or other tissues being common. Diagnosis is made through laboratory tests to measure clotting factor levels.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 668.

questions.text: The cause of Fetal Hydantoin Syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Phenytoin 

Fetal hydantoin syndrome is a characteristic pattern of mental and physical birth defects that results from maternal use of the anti-seizure (anticonvulsant) drug phenytoin (Dilantin) during pregnancy.
  • The range and severity of associated abnormalities will vary greatly from one infant to another. However, characteristic features may include distinctive skull and facial features, growth deficiencies, underdeveloped (hypoplastic) nails of the fingers and toes, and/or mild developmental delays.
  • Other findings occasionally associated with this syndrome include cleft lip and palate, a head circumference that is smaller than would be expected based upon an infant’s age and gender (microcephaly), and skeletal malformations particularly of the fingers or hands.

* [Extra Edge]: Teratogenic Drugs


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 441.

questions.text: Pick the incorrect statement regarding Opioid receptor antagonists.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Naloxone is more potent than Naltrexone

Option 1, 2 and 4 are regarding Naltrexone and Naloxone
  • Naltrexone differs from naloxone in being orally active and having a long duration of action (1–2 days) which makes it suitable for ‘opioid blockade’ therapy of postaddicts. 
  • Naltrexone is more potent than naloxone.
  • There is evidence that naltrexone decreases the craving for alcohol in chronic alcoholics by increasing baseline β-endorphin release, and it has been approved by the FDA for this purpose.
  • Methylnaltrexone bromide and Naloxone is approved for the treatment of constipation in patients with opioid-induced constipation (OIC) with chronic noncancer pain.
  • late-stage advanced illness naloxegol, alvimopan approved for the treatment of postoperative ileus following bowel resection surgery.
Option 3 Nalmefene pure opioid antagonist lacks hepatotoxicity of naltrexone, has higher oral bioavailability and is longer acting than Naloxone.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 512.

choices.text: Inhibit conversion of levodopa to dopamine in the CNS

questions.text: The reason why L-Dopa is combined with Carbidopa in the treatment of parkinsonism is to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Inhibit peripheral decarboxylation of levodopa

Levodopa is metabolized by dopa decarboxylase in the whole body. 90% of levodopa gets metabolized into dopamine in the periphery and only a small amount reaches the brain

Carbidopa is an analog of levodopa. It does not cross the blood brain barrier. So if carbidopa is given with levodopa , it competitively blocks dopa decarboxylase in the periphery preventing peripheral metabolism of levodopa. Thus, it helps in reducing the dopamine related peripheral side effects and increase central concentration of dopamine. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 457.

questions.text: The following statement about Phenytoin is false:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Stimulates insulin secretion

Phenytoin follows Michaelis Menten kinetics, elimination changes from first order to zero order kinetics when dose is increased beyond saturation levels.

Option 2 :  Causes foetal hydantoin syndrome – microcephaly, cleft lip/palate, hypoplastic phalanges

Option 3 : Phenytoin is highly bound to plasma protien and thus has low volume of distribution.

Option 4 : This is a false statement, phenytoin inhibits glucose-stimulated insulin secretion by interfering with Ca2+ uptake via voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 393.

questions.text: It is prohibited to use MAO inhibitors with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Pethidine
 
  • Pethidine undergoes hydrolysis and is excreted in the kidney. Some amount (1%) is metabolized by Dealkylation into Normeperidine which then undergoes hydrolysis.
  • MAO inhibitors block this hydrolysis leading to accumulation of toxic Normeperidine which is neurotoxic.
Thus, MAO inhibitors are contraindicated with Pethidine.

questions.text: Serotonin syndrome cannot be precipitated by:

Correct Answer is (Option 1) Chlorpromazine

  • CPZ produces indifference to surroundings, paucity of thought, psychomotor slowing, emotional quietening, reduction in initiative and tendency to go off to sleep from which the subject is easily arousable.
  • Spontaneous movements are minimized but slurring of speech, ataxia or motor incoordination does not occur.
  • This is mostly perceived to be unpleasant and has been referred to as the ‘neuroleptic syndrome’.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 464, 488.

questions.text: Which of the given statements about Mycophenolate Mofetil is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Most common adverse effect is Nephrotoxicity

Nephrotoxicity is not the most common adverse effect of Mycophenolate Mofetil (MMF). While MMF can have adverse effects on the kidneys, the most common adverse effects associated with MMF include gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.

Rather, MMF+ Glucocorticoid + Sirolimus is a non-nephrotoxic combination used in patients developing renal toxicity with Cyclosporine/ tacrolimus.

Other reported adverse effects include bone marrow suppression, increased risk of infections, and increased susceptibility to malignancies.
The correct information about Mycophenolate Mofetil is:
  1. Used in Transplant rejection: Mycophenolate Mofetil is commonly used as an immunosuppressive medication in organ transplantation to prevent rejection. It inhibits the proliferation of T and B lymphocytes, which are involved in the immune response against the transplanted organ.
  2. It is a prodrug and converted to Mycophenolic acid: Mycophenolate Mofetil is a prodrug that is rapidly and completely converted to its active metabolite, Mycophenolic acid (MPA), in the body. MPA is responsible for the immunosuppressive effects of Mycophenolate Mofetil.
  3. Is not used with Azathioprine: Mycophenolate Mofetil is often used as an alternative to Azathioprine in immunosuppressive regimens, particularly in organ transplantation. But it should not be combined with Azathioprine. These medications have similar mechanisms of action but different side effect profiles, and the choice between them depends on individual patient factors and clinical considerations.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 942.

questions.text: Select the drug that is recommended for the treatment of Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Lepirudin
 

HIT
Definition Immune reaction causing low platelets and clot formation after heparin use.
Onset 5–10 days after starting heparin (earlier with prior exposure).
Causes Antibodies against platelet factor 4 (PF4)-heparin complex.
Symptoms - Platelet drop >50%- Blood clots (DVT, PE, stroke).
Treatment 1. Stop all heparin (including flushes).
2. Start non-heparin anticoagulant:
- Argatroban
- Fondaparinux
- Lepirudin (direct thrombin inhibitor).
3. Avoid warfarin until platelets recover.
Complications Blood clots (DVT, PE, limb ischemia, stroke).

Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor and is one of the options for anticoagulation in HIT. However, it is less commonly used compared to newer agents.


Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 715.

questions.text: Allopurinol is used to treat:

questions.text: Select the most significant role of Bradykinin in acute inflammation.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Mediation of pain
 
  • Bradykinin, a potent vasoactive peptide, is involved in acute inflammation and plays a significant role in mediating pain.
  • It sensitizes nociceptors (pain receptors) and induces the release of pain mediators, such as prostaglandins and substance P.
  • Bradykinin also promotes vasodilation and increased vascular permeability, contributing to the inflammatory response.

questions.text: Heterozygous sickle cell anemia helps to protect against:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Malaria

Heterozygous sickle cell anemia (carrier state) provides some protection against malaria. The presence of sickle hemoglobin in red blood cells makes them less suitable for the growth and survival of the malaria parasite. As a result, individuals with sickle cell trait have a reduced risk of developing severe forms of malaria.

questions.text: Which is most characteristic feature of apoptosis on light microscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2): Nuclear compaction
 
  • The most characteristic feature of apoptosis on light microscopy is nuclear compaction or pyknosis.
  • Pyknosis refers to the shrinkage and condensation of the nucleus, resulting in a dense, darkly stained appearance.
  • Other features of apoptosis include cell shrinkage, chromatin fragmentation, membrane blebbing, and formation of apoptotic bodies are seen in electron microscopy. 
*[Extra Edge]: Irreversible cell injury

questions.text: The following is not a feature of apoptosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): Cellular swelling
 
  • Cellular swelling is not a feature of apoptosis but rather a characteristic of necrosis.
  • Apoptosis is characterized by nuclear condensation, intact cell membrane, cytoplasmic eosinophilia, and the absence of cellular swelling.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 43.

questions.text: PNH is linked to deficiencies in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 4) All of the above
 
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is associated with deficiencies in multiple proteins that are anchored to the cell membrane by glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI).
  • Deficiencies of DAF (decay accelerating factor), MIRL (membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis), and other GPI-anchored proteins contribute to the pathogenesis of PNH.
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a rare, acquired disorder of the blood characterized by the abnormal breakdown of red blood cells (hemolysis) and the presence of dark urine in the morning. It is caused by a mutation in the PIGA gene, leading to a deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins on the surface of blood cells. This results in increased sensitivity to complement-mediated destruction.
  • PNH can lead to anemia, fatigue, and increased susceptibility to infections and blood clots. Diagnosis is made through flow cytometry to detect the absence of GPI-anchored proteins.
  • Treatment options include supportive care, blood transfusions, and targeted therapies such as eculizumab.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 648.

choices.text: GPI Anchored Protein (Glycosyl phosphatidyl inositol anchored proteins)

questions.text: PNH is associated with deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) GPI Anchored Protein (Glycosyl phosphatidyl inositol anchored proteins)
 
  • PNH is primarily associated with a deficiency of GPI-anchored proteins on the surface of red blood cells, leukocytes, and platelets. The most notable GPI-anchored protein deficiency in PNH is CD55 (decay accelerating factor, DAF) and CD59 (membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis, MIRL).
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a rare, acquired disorder of the blood characterized by the abnormal breakdown of red blood cells (hemolysis) and the presence of dark urine in the morning. It is caused by a mutation in the PIGA gene, leading to a deficiency of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins on the surface of blood cells. This results in increased sensitivity to complement-mediated destruction.
  • PNH can lead to anemia, fatigue, and increased susceptibility to infections and blood clots. Diagnosis is made through flow cytometry to detect the absence of GPI-anchored proteins.
  • Treatment options include supportive care, blood transfusions, and targeted therapies such as eculizumab.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 648.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fibrous endocardial thickening of right ventricle, tricuspid valve & pulmonary valve
 
  • Carcinoid heart disease is associated with fibrous endocardial thickening primarily involving the right side of the heart, including the right ventricle, tricuspid valve, and pulmonary valve.

questions.text: A female recounts a history of escalating shortness of breath. Histology reveals a patchy heterogeneous fibrosis with a number of fibroblastic foci. The following is the likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Usual interstitial pneumonia
 
  • The described histological findings of patchy heterogeneous fibrosis with fibroblastic foci are consistent with usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).
  • UIP is the histological pattern seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), a chronic progressive lung disease characterized by fibrosis and architectural distortion of the lung parenchyma.
  • In UIP, there is a combination of areas of normal lung, fibrosis with honeycomb changes, and fibroblastic foci representing sites of active fibroblast proliferation.
  • Fibroblastic foci are aggregates of activated fibroblasts associated with myofibroblasts that contribute to the ongoing fibrotic process in UIP.
Other patterns of interstitial lung disease, such as non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) and desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP), have distinct histological features and clinical associations.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2190.

questions.text: Renal cell cancer with a chromophobe form is connected to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Monosomy of 1 and Y (-1, -Y)
 
  • Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is associated with specific chromosomal losses, particularly monosomy of chromosomes 1 and Y (-1, -Y). Monosomy refers to the loss of one copy of a particular chromosome in a cell.
  • These genetic abnormalities are frequently detected in chromophobe renal cell carcinoma and can be helpful in its diagnosis.
  • Other renal cell carcinoma subtypes, such as clear cell carcinoma and papillary carcinoma, have distinct chromosomal alterations.
  • Chromophobe renal carcinoma is made up of pale eosinophilic cells, often with a perinuclear halo, arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels.
Other options: -
VHL - Clear cell cancer 
Trisomy 7/17- Papillary cell cancer 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 950.

questions.text: Granulomatous pathology is linked to all of the following conditions, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Polyarteritis Nodosa (Classic PAN)
 
  • Granulomatous pathology is not typically associated with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN).
  • PAN is a necrotizing vasculitis that primarily affects medium-sized arteries and does not involve small vessels.
  • It is characterized by transmural inflammation, fibrinoid necrosis, and aneurysmal formation in affected arteries.
  • Wegener's granulomatosis, Takayasu arteritis, and giant cell arteritis are examples of vasculitides that can exhibit granulomatous inflammation.
  • In Wegener's granulomatosis, necrotizing granulomas involving the respiratory tract and necrotizing vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels are typically seen.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 513.

questions.text: Electron microscopy is used to diagnose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alport's syndrome
 
  • Electron microscopy is used to diagnose Alport's syndrome, a hereditary disorder affecting the glomerular basement membrane.
  • Alport's syndrome is characterized by the presence of thinning, splitting, and lamellation of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) when examined under an electron microscope.
  • These ultrastructural changes in the GBM result from mutations in genes encoding type IV collagen, a major component of the GBM.
  • The characteristic electron microscopy findings help differentiate Alport's syndrome from other forms of glomerulonephritis.
* [Extra Edge]: Electron microscopy of Alport syndrome

Early Alport or carriers of Alport show diffuse thinning of GBMs. In established Alport, there are irregular thin and thickened areas with splintered and irregular multi-laminated appearance of the lamina densa, with short stubs of fibrils at right angles to the GBM, irregular lucent areas interspersed with thickened areas of the lamina densa, resulting in a so-called basket-weave pattern. There are no immune complexes, and foot processes, particularly in sclerosed glomeruli, may show effacement.


Fig: lamellated and basket-weave appearance (electron microscopy)

* Vasculitis Types:



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 922.

questions.text: Which of the following is the paraganglioma's most distinctive ultrastructural feature as seen under an electron microscope?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Dense core neuroendocrine granules
 
  • Paragangliomas, which are neuroendocrine tumors arising from extra-adrenal paraganglia, exhibit dense core neuroendocrine granules when examined under an electron microscope.
  • These dense core granules contain various hormones and neuropeptides that are characteristic of neuroendocrine cells.
  • The presence of dense core granules is one of the distinguishing features of neuroendocrine tumors and can aid in their identification on electron microscopy.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 746.

questions.text: Which of these causes hypercoagulation in nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Loss of Antithrombin III
 
  • Nephrotic syndrome is associated with the loss of antithrombin III, a natural anticoagulant. Antithrombin III inhibits several coagulation factors, including thrombin (factor IIa) and factors IXa, Xa, XIa, and XIIa.
  • The urinary loss of antithrombin III in nephrotic syndrome contributes to a prothrombotic state, increasing the risk of hypercoagulability and thrombotic events.
  • Other changes in the coagulation system, such as decreased levels of protein C and protein S, can also contribute to the hypercoagulable state in nephrotic syndrome
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 911.

questions.text: Pick the marker that is specific for Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST).
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) CD 117
 
  • DOG1 and CD117 were the most sensitive and specific antibodies used in GIST diagnosis.
  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are characterized by the expression of CD 117, also known as c-kit protein.
  • CD 117 is a transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinase that plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of GIST. Immunohistochemical staining for CD 117 is commonly used to identify and diagnose GIST, as it is highly specific for this tumor type.

Other markers, such as CD 34 and S-100, may also be expressed in GIST, but CD 117 is considered the most specific and sensitive marker for GIST.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 778.

questions.text: In which of these inheritance patterns given below are males more commonly affected than females?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: X-linked recessive

Males are more commonly affected than females in diseases which have X-linked recessive inheritance.
 
  • In X-linked recessive inheritance, the gene responsible for the disorder is located on the X chromosome.
  • Since, males have one X chromosome and females have two X chromosomes, the presence of a single copy of the mutated gene on the X chromosome in males is sufficient to cause the disorder.
  • In contrast, females need to have two copies of the mutated gene (one on each X chromosome) to be affected.
  • Since males have only one X chromosome, they have a higher chance of inheriting and expressing X-linked recessive disorders.
  • Females, on the other hand, have a second X chromosome that can act as a "backup" and may carry a normal copy of the gene, reducing the likelihood of exhibiting the disorder.
Examples of X-Linked Recessive diseases are
 
  1. Hemophilia A
  2. Hemophilia B (Christmas disease)
  3. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD)
  4. Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD)
  5. X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA)
  6. Fragile X syndrome
  7. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome
  8. Hunter syndrome (Mucopolysaccharidosis II)
 

Reference - Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 640

* A FEW IMPORTANT POINTS ON ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANCE FREQUENTLY ASKED: -
 
  • Beta lactamase production is the most common mechanism of resistance. This causes resistance in gram positive organisms like (Streptococcus, Actinomyces); gram negative organisms like (Neisseria, spirochetes)
  • Alteration in Penicillin binding proteins lead to resistance against drugs like Methicillin (MRSA)—Staphylococcus aureus is gram positive organism
  • Cephalosporin resistance – Presence of enzyme like cephalosporinase
  • Carbapenem resistance – Presence of Carbapenems
  • Vancomycin resistance – Amino acid modification of D-ALA, D-ALA
  • Aminoglycoside resistance – Bacterial Transferase enzyme
  • Chloramphenicol resistance – Plasmid coded acetyltransferase
  • Tetracycline resistance – Changes in uptake/ efflux by plasmid coded transport pumps
  • Linezolid resistance – Point mutation of rRNA
  • Sulphonamide resistance – Alteration of enzymes Bacterial Dihydropteroate synthase
  • Fluroquinolone resistance – Chromosome coded mutation in DNA gyrase, plasmid mediated resistance, efflux pumps
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 767.

questions.text: Where are primary impact injuries most commonly seen?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Legs

Impact injury is the damage caused by the collision of a body with a moving or stationary object.
The best example is collision of a person walking on the road with a moving car.
Primary impact injury is caused by initial strike, i.e., the first part of the vehicle that strikes the victim (usually legs). Secondary impact injuries are injuries produced due to an impact between the body part and the vehicle for the second time. Secondary injuries are injuries not by the car but due to the person falling down on the road i.e., ground impact injury.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: Within five years of her marriage, a woman passed away under mysterious circumstances. The frequent dowry demands made by her in-laws were a source of complaint for her parents. Which of the following sections permits the magistrate to order an autopsy in such a case?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Section 176 CrPc

Section 176 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) in India pertains to the inquiry by a Magistrate into the cause of death in the following circumstances: Death occurring in police custody Death occurring in judicial custody Death occurring under suspicious circumstances
Option 1: Section 174 CrPc pertains to the procedure for the investigation of cases of unnatural deaths by police inquest.
Option 3: Section 304 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) deals with the offense of culpable homicide not amounting to murder. It is further divided into two parts: Section 304(a) and Section 304(b). 304(a) – Death due to medical negligence 304(b) – Dowry death
Option 4: Section 302 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) deals with the offense of murder. Mens rea, which refers to the mental state of the accused, is an essential element of murder and actus rea, guilty act both must be present.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 7.

questions.text: Which of the following bullets leaves a mark visible enough for someone to perceive it:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Tracer bullet.

Tracer bullets leave a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the strike of shot can be observed. They enable the shooter to make aiming corrections.

* Other types of bullets:
  • Tandem bullet: Two bullets are ejected one after giving a piggy back effect. This may occur due to the defect in weapon.
  • Dum Dum bullet: It has a chiselled-out tip that fragments extensively on impact.
  • Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorus which ignites on hitting the target.
  • Ricochet bullet: The bullet first strikes an intermediate object, gets reflected in a way that it changes direction and then strikes the target.
  • Yawning bullet: Moves in an irregular way and produces a keyhole type of entry wound.
  • Tumbling bullet: Rotates a whole 360 degree i.e., end on end before hitting the target 
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 215.

questions.text: ASHA is posted at which level?
questions.solution:
Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) is a community health worker instituted by the government of India as part of the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM).
  • ASHA workers are posted at the village level to act as a bridge between the community and the healthcare system, ensuring that health services are accessible to the rural population.
  • Their role includes promoting healthy behaviors, ensuring immunization, assisting with healthcare access, and promoting institutional deliveries.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 701.

questions.text: What is movement across socioeconomic levels called?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Social Mobility

Social mobility is the change in a person’s socioeconomic status either in comparison to their parents i.e. Inter-generational mobility or in their own lifetime i.e. Intra-generational mobility. It can occur in any direction, upgradation or downgradation.

Social mobility

Indian society is rigidly based on caste system. There is little social mobility, i.e., people do not change their caste or religion. In other words, Indian society is a “closed-class” system. There are societies known as the “open class societies” where movement of the social ladder is unrestricted, on the basis of achievement or gaining wealth. Open class societies are therefore more progressive where people according to their ability can go up the social ladder. In closed-class systems, it is difficult to make reforms without meeting resistance of the people.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 744.

questions.text: What does "JSY" stand for?
questions.solution:
Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) is a safe motherhood intervention under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM).
  • The scheme aims to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women.
  • JSY provides financial incentives to encourage women to give birth in healthcare facilities rather than at home, where risks to mother and child can be higher.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 521.

questions.text: The following made primary healthcare available:

  • Chaired by Dr. A. Lakshmanaswamy Mudaliar, the committee aimed to reform medical education and healthcare delivery in the country.

choices.text: Intervention based on assessment of community needs

questions.text: Which of the following best exemplifies the highest level of community involvement?
questions.solution:
The highest level of community involvement is when the community itself is actively involved in the planning of interventions.
  • This level of participation indicates that the community members are not just recipients of services or passive participants but are actively engaged in identifying issues, deciding on the interventions, and planning how to implement these interventions.
  • This represents a high degree of ownership, empowerment, and sustainability of the initiatives.
Intervention based on assessment of community needs (Option 2) typically involves external agents assessing the needs and designing interventions accordingly, which may or may not fully involve the community in the decision-making process.

Provision of resources by community (Option 3) shows a significant level of involvement, but it focuses on the community contributing resources rather than being involved in planning.

Community supports and cooperates with workers (Option 4) is a lower level of involvement, where the community cooperates with interventions designed and implemented by others but does not lead or plan them.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 694.

It is expressed as a rate and not ratio

questions.text: Which of the following regarding maternal mortality ratio (MMR) is false?
questions.solution:
Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is a crucial indicator of maternal health, measuring the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in a given time period.
  • To calculate MMR, the total number of live births is used as the dominator.
  • This denominator reflects the population at risk of maternal deaths, as it includes all women who gave birth during the specified period.
  • In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 635.

The perinatal mortality rate (PMR) is calculated using the following parameters during a particular time period:
  • Late fetal deaths or stillbirths >1000 g - correlates to 28 weeks of gestation
  • Early neonatal deaths - from birth to 7 days of life
  • Live births >1000 g


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 642.

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't constitute a necessary part of primary healthcare?
questions.solution:
Primary health care is based on principles such as
  • accessibility,
  • community participation,
  • health promotion, and
  • the provision of essential services like immunization, health education, and essential drugs.


While cost-effectiveness is important in healthcare delivery, it is not specifically defined as a fundamental component of primary healthcare.
The other options (provision of essential drugs, immunization, and health education) are core elements of primary healthcare as outlined by the Alma-Ata Declaration.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 694.

questions.text: Which of the following encapsulates a recent medical trend?
questions.solution:
Community participation has become a prominent trend in modern healthcare, emphasizing the involvement of the community in health planning, decision-making, and intervention strategies.
  • This trend reflects a shift towards empowering communities to take an active role in their health, ensuring that healthcare interventions are more effective, sustainable, and culturally appropriate.
  • While qualitative inquiry, equitable distribution, and primary healthcare are all important concepts, community participation represents a specific trend in the evolving landscape of public health.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 694.

choices.text: Emphasis on management of sick neonates over sick older children
Treatment is aimed at more than one disease at a time

questions.text: IMNCI is distinct from IMCI in every way with the exception of:
questions.solution:
The Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illnesses (IMNCI) and the Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI) are approaches designed to reduce child mortality and improve child health.
  • IMNCI is an expansion of IMCI that includes a focus on the neonatal period (0-7 days) and emphasizes the management of sick neonates.
  • However, both approaches share the principle of addressing multiple diseases and health issues simultaneously rather than focusing on just one disease at a time.
  • This holistic approach is a cornerstone of both IMNCI and IMCI, making option 4 the correct answer.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 655.

questions.text: How many days must pass after acute flaccid paralysis in order to detect any residual weakness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 60 days

60 days after the onset of clinical symptoms the patients with acute flaccid paralysis are evaluated to detect the presence of any residual weakness.

Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) is an infectious disease caused by a number of viruses, including poliovirus.
  • Due to the dangerous nature of the virus, AFP surveillance is conducted by health departments all over the world to monitor for and prevent transmission.
 
  • As part of an AFP surveillance program, all cases of AFP are re-evaluated for residual paralysis at 60 days, to determine whether or not the paralysis was caused by poliovirus.
 
  • This helps health departments determine whether or not a given outbreak is ongoing or has ceased.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 242.

questions.text: India aims to eliminate which of the following diseases by 2015:
questions.solution:
India set the goal to eliminate Kala Azar (Visceral Leishmaniasis) by 2015.
  • Kala Azar is a parasitic disease transmitted by sandflies, and it primarily affects the poor in rural areas. The elimination target refers to reducing the incidence of Kala Azar to less than 1 case per 10,000 population at the sub-district level.
  • Malaria and Tuberculosis are significant public health challenges, but the target for elimination of these diseases was set for later years, not 2015.
  • Filariasis elimination was also targeted for a later date, with the goal being extended to beyond 2015.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 480.

questions.text: According to the NPCB, the screening technique for preventing diabetic retinopathy-related blindness entails:
questions.solution:
The National Program for Control of Blindness (NPCB) emphasizes the importance of regular screening for diabetic retinopathy to prevent vision loss. High-risk screening typically involves examining individuals with diabetes at regular intervals to detect early signs of retinopathy. This can include:

  1. Dilated Eye Examinations: Optometrists or ophthalmologists examine the retina for any changes.
  2. Fundus Photography: Capturing images of the retina for analysis.
  3. Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Non-invasive imaging to assess retinal layers and detect swelling.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 503.

questions.text: The following descriptions of the annual rate of infection (ARI) for tuberculosis are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 1% ARI corresponds 75 new cases of smear positive TB per 100,00 population

ANNUAL INFECTION RATE :-
  • It is defined as the percentage of population under study who will be newly infected by tuberculosis among the non infected during the course of 1 year.
  • It is the annual risk of getting infected in a given community.
  • It is also known as ‘ TUBERCULIN CONVERSION INDEX ‘
  • 1% annual risk of infection corresponds to 50 new smear positive cases of pulmonary TB per 100,000 general population
  • It is one of the best parameters for evaluating the tuberculosis problem and its trend.
  • The higher is the rate the higher is the problem.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 210.

questions.text: A standard 'z-score' is associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Normal distribution

THE FOLLOWING ARE THE IMPORTANT POINTS TO REMEMBER REGARDING Z SCORE :-
  • Z-score  or  standard score  describes how far a data point is from the mean. 
  • It can also be described as a measure of how many  standard deviations below or above the population mean , a  raw score is.
  • A Z-score can be placed on a  normal distribution curve.  
  • It’s value ranges from -3 standard deviations   up to +3 standard deviations .
  •  In order to use a z-score, you need to know the mean and  the population standard deviation .
  • Z-scores are a way to compare results to a “normal” population.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent investigations needs to be carried out right away in order to most effectively confirm a non-matched blood transfusion reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Direct Coomb's test
 
  • A non-matched blood transfusion reaction occurs when there is a mismatch between the recipient's blood type and the donor blood type. In this situation, the recipient's immune system may produce antibodies against the donor blood cells.
 
  • The Direct Coomb's test is used to detect these antibodies that have attached to the patient's own red blood cells. It helps confirm the presence of immune-mediated hemolysis, which is a characteristic feature of a non-matched blood transfusion reaction.

choices.text: Occurs due to rapid filling of the ventricles during atrial systole

questions.text: The assertions about the third heart sound (S3) that follow are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
S3 is a low-pitched sound (25–50Hz) which is heard in early diastole, following the second heart sound.
 
  • The third heart sound (S3) occurs during the rapid filling phase of ventricular diastole. It can be a normal finding in children, adolescents, and young adults; however, in older patients, it signifies heart failure.
  • A left-sided S3 is a low-pitched sound best heard over the LV apex. A right-sided S3 is usually better heard over the lower left sternal border and becomes louder with inspiration.
  • A left-sided S3 in patients with chronic heart failure is predictive of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. Interestingly, an S3 is equally prevalent among heart failure patients with preserved and reduced LV ejection fraction.
  • S3 is also heard in those states in which left heart handles increased load of blood volume like in ASD and VSD.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1820.

questions.text: A young asymptomatic female is observed to have a Mid systolic Click on routine examination. Valves are likely to show:
questions.solution:
• It appears that the clinical signs indicated in the question point to Mitral Valve Prolapse Syndrome (MVP).In the event of an inspection of the cells and tissues, a myxomatous degeneration and the falling back of the mitral valve are likely results to be seen in Mitral Valve Prolapse Syndrome.
 
  • Mitral valve prolapse syndrome is a condition in which the mitral valve, which separates the upper and lower chambers of the heart, bulges abnormally into the left atrium. It is the most common form of heart valve disorder.
 
  • Symptoms of mitral valve prolapse range from no symptoms to a wide variety of uncomfortable symptoms and can include chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Other common symptoms may include dizziness, fainting, anxiety, dry cough, and significant fatigue.
 
  • Patients may also suffer from a palpitation when the mitral valve fails to close properly and a murmur may be heard. In some cases, mitral valve prolapse can cause mitral regurgitation  in the valve, leading to even greater issues such as heart arrhythmia and congestive heart failure.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2000.

questions.text: Beck's Triad can be observed in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cardiac tamponade

Beck's triad consists of three classic signs seen in cardiac tamponade, which is a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space:
  1. Hypotension: Low blood pressure due to reduced cardiac output.
  2. Muffled heart sounds: Distant, muffled, or soft heart sounds heard on auscultation.
  3. Jugular venous distention: Distended jugular veins in the neck due to increased venous pressure.
While the other options (constrictive pericarditis, right ventricular myocardial infarction, and restrictive cardiomyopathy) may have similar manifestations, they are not specifically associated with Beck's triad.

Physiology:
  • The fall in arterial blood pressure results from pericardial fluid accumulation inside the pericardial sac, which decreases the maximum size of the ventricles. This limits diastolic expansion (filling) which results in a lower EDV (End Diastolic Volume) which reduces stroke volume, a major determinant of systolic blood pressure.
  • The rising central venous pressure is evidenced by distended jugular veins while in a non-supine position. It is caused by reduced diastolic filling of the right ventricle, due to pressure from the adjacent expanding pericardial sac. This results in a backup of fluid into the veins draining into the heart, most notably, the jugular veins. In severe hypovolemia, the neck veins may not be distended.
  • The suppressed heart sounds occur due to the muffling effects of the fluid surrounding the heart.

Clinical use: Although the full triad is present only in a minority of cases of acute cardiac tamponade, presence of the triad is considered pathognomonic for the condition.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2021.

questions.text: A patient is seen with the following values: pH 7.5, pCO2 28mmHg, and 16 meQ/L of HCO3. Which of the subsequent options best sums up the compensating mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Metabolic Acidosis
 
  • A patient with pH 7.5 with pCO2 of 28 mmHg [Normal: 35-45] suggests that the patient is having Respiratory alkalosis.
 
  • Compensation for the same would be done via Metabolic acidosis (the patient is having low HCO3 16 suggesting metabolic compensation has started).
  • Hence, the Correct answer is option (4) - Metabolic Acidosis.
Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same


Please note - The question is asking about the compensating mechanism - not the primary acid-base abnormality.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: An anxious 29-year-old woman appears with a four-month history of increasing dyspnea and exercise intolerance. Her FEV1/FVC is 86% and FVC is 90%. DLCO is 50% of expected. After exercise, oxygen saturation was seen to fall from 92% to 86%. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
• Primary pulmonary hypertension is an idiopathic condition wherein a young adult develops sudden progressive dyspnea and exercise intolerance over a few months due to narrowing of Pulmonary arteries resulting in PAH.
  • This is due to a genetic mutation in BMPR 2 gene.
 
  • In PAH, an isolated reduction in diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is a classic finding.

  • The right heart catheterisation (RHC) remains the gold standard test to both establish the diagnosis of PH and guide selection of appropriate medical therapy.

The hemodynamic criteria for diagnosing PH requires:
  1. mPAP >20 mmHg
  2. pulmonary artery wedge pressure (PAWP) (or left ventricular end-diastolic pressure [LVEDP]) ≤15 mmHg or >15 mmHg, respectively
  3. PVR ≥3.0 Wood units (WU)


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2123, 2124.

questions.text: Which of these conditions is most frequently associated with accelerated idioventricular rhythm (AIVR)?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Myocardial Reperfusion
 
  • Three or more ventricular beats at a rate slower than 100 beats/min are termed an AIVR.
  • Automaticity is the likely mechanism, although in some rare cases, a reentrant circuit utilizing diseased myocardium can cause AIVR.
  • Idioventricular rhythms are common during acute MI and may emerge during sinus bradycardia.
  • This rhythm is also common in patients with cardiomyopathies or sleep apnea. It can also be idiopathic, often emerging when the sinus rate slows during sleep.
  • Treatment: Atropine may be administered to increase the sinus rates if hemodynamic instability is a concern.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1917.

questions.text: During a normal laboratory check, a patient's HBsAg status is discovered to be positive. Other hepatitis serological testing are unremarkable. His liver enzymes are within the normal range, and he exhibits no clinical symptoms. Which of the following options most accurately sums up his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The above clinical scenario with HBsAg positive and other serological marker negative and with Normal aminotransferase levels points the diagnosis most probably towards Inactive HBV carrier.
 
  • In patients with chronic hepatitis B and normal aminotransferase activity in the absence of HBeAg, serial testing over time is often required to distinguish between inactive carriage and HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis B with fluctuating virologic and necroinflammatory activity.
 
  • Such patients have IgG anti-HBc in serum; anti-HBs is either undetected or detected at low titer against the opposite subtype specificity of the antigen. These patients may (1) be inactive carriers; (2) have low-grade, mild chronic hepatitis; or (3) have moderate to severe chronic hepatitis with or without cirrhosis.

questions.text: A male patient is found to have anti-HBe antibody positivity, HBs Ag antigen positivity, and HBe Ag antigen negativity. While SGOT and SGPT are raised to 6 times the upper limit of normal value, HBV DNA copies are detected to be 100,000/ml. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: HBV precore mutant
 
  • The patient has anti-HBe antibody positivity, HBsAg positivity, and HBeAg negativity. These serological markers suggest a transition from the immune tolerant phase to the immune clearance phase of chronic HBV infection. The presence of raised SGOT and SGPT levels indicates liver inflammation.
 
  • The key feature in this case is the detection of HBV DNA copies at 100,000/ml. A precore mutant HBV infection is characterized by the absence of HBeAg production due to a mutation in the precore region of the HBV genome. This leads to a decrease or absence of HBeAg in the serum, despite ongoing viral replication.
 
  • Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this case is HBV precore mutant infection.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2576.

questions.text: Plasma urea/ creatinine ratio of 20:1 may be seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Pre-renal failure
A plasma urea/creatinine ratio of 20:1 may be seen in pre-renal failure.

Pre-renal failure refers to a condition where there is reduced blood flow to the kidneys, leading to decreased filtration of waste products. This can be caused by factors such as dehydration, hypovolemia (low blood volume), or decreased cardiac output. In pre-renal failure, the kidneys try to conserve water and sodium, resulting in increased reabsorption of urea in the renal tubules and a higher urea/creatinine ratio.
 
  • Rhabdomyolysis (Option 1) is a condition characterized by the breakdown of muscle tissue, which can lead to an increase in creatinine levels, but the urea/creatinine ratio is typically not significantly elevated.
 
  • Ureteric calculi (Option 2) refers to kidney stones that have migrated into the ureter. While it can cause obstruction and kidney dysfunction, it does not typically result in a markedly elevated urea/creatinine ratio.
 
  • Chronic glomerulonephritis (Option 4) is a condition involving inflammation and damage to the glomeruli of the kidneys. It can lead to impaired renal function, but the urea/creatinine ratio may not be as high as in pre-renal failure. Please note that the plasma/urine creatinine ratio is useful in distinguishing between pre-renal and intrinsic renal causes of AKI. A ratio of less than 20:1 suggests pre-renal AKI, while a ratio greater than 20:1 is indicative of intrinsic renal disease.

​​​​​​​Difference between Pre-renal and Intrinsic Renal AKI:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2303.

choices.text: Low serum ceruloplasmin and low urinary copper
Low serum ceruloplasmin and high urinary copper
High serum ceruloplasmin and low urinary copper
High Serum ceruloplasmin and high urinary copper

questions.text: Which is the accurate statement about Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Low serum ceruloplasmin and high urinary copper 
 
  • Wilson’s disease occours due to mutation in ATP 7b gene on chromosome 13q
  • Copper metabolism is impaired
  • Copper is absorbed from small intestine by DMT1
  • Inside the epithelial cells binds to metallothionien which sequesters copper. Enough metallothienin is present in children of less than 3 years and so Wilson disease is seen between 3-20 years of age.
  • Liver cells also carry the CMT1 protein, and metallothionein and ATOX1 bind it inside the cell, but here, ATP7B links copper to ceruloplasmin and releases it into the bloodstream, as well as removing excess copper by secreting it into bile.
  • In Wilson’s, Copper accumulates in the liver tissue; ceruloplasmin is still secreted, but in a form that lacks copper (termed apo-ceruloplasmin) and is rapidly degraded in the bloodstream. Thus ceruloplasmin levels are low.
  • This accumulation of copper in the liver causes oxidative damage by fentons chemistry which leads to chronic hepatitis, fibrosis and cirrhosis.
  • The liver also releases copper into the bloodstream that is not bound to ceruloplasmin. This free copper precipitates throughout the body, but particularly in the kidneys, eyes, and brain.
  • Clinical features
  1. Brain – copper deposits in the basal ganglia, globes pallidus and putamen leading to neuropsychiatric symptoms like bradykinesia, Parkinsonism, tremors, ataxia and dystonia.
  2. Eyes –  Kayser–Fleischer rings (KF rings) may be visible in the cornea of the eyes, the occur due to copper deposition in the descemet membrane.
  3. Kidneys – renal tubular acidosis
  4. Heart – cardiomyopathy and cardiac arrhythmias
  • Serum copper is low, which may seem paradoxical given that Wilson's disease is a disease of copper excess. However, 95% of plasma copper is carried by ceruloplasmin, which is often low in Wilson's disease. Urine copper is elevated in Wilson's disease.


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 322

questions.text: Which of these is not associated with Thymoma?

questions.text: Plasmapheresis is not used in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cholinergic crisis 
 
Plasmapheresis, also known as therapeutic plasma exchange, is a procedure in which plasma is separated from the blood and replaced with a substitution fluid. It is used as a therapeutic intervention in various conditions involving autoimmune or immune-mediated processes.

Plasmapheresis is commonly used in the following conditions:
 
  1. Myasthenic crisis: Plasmapheresis can be used as a treatment for acute exacerbations of myasthenia gravis when there is respiratory muscle weakness or significant bulbar involvement.
  2. Guillain-Barré syndrome: Plasmapheresis is an effective treatment option for severe cases of Guillain-Barré syndrome to remove circulating autoantibodies and inflammatory mediators.
  3. Polymyositis: Plasmapheresis may be considered in select cases of severe, refractory polymyositis, especially when associated with significant muscle weakness or respiratory compromise.
 
  • However, plasmapheresis is not typically indicated in Cholinergic crisis.
  • It is not due to antibodies formation. 
  • Cholinergic crisis is an acute exacerbation of symptoms in patients with myasthenia gravis due to excessive cholinesterase inhibitor medication (such as pyridostigmine) intake.
  • The management of Cholinergic crisis involves reducing or stopping the cholinesterase inhibitor medication and providing supportive care.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3514, 3515.
