questions.text: Antiphospholipid Antibody (APLA) syndrome is not associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Bleeding disorders
 
  • APLA syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies in the blood, which can lead to an increased risk of thrombotic (clotting) events and pregnancy complications.
 
  • The main clinical manifestations of APLA syndrome include thrombotic disorders such as deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, stroke, and arterial thrombosis. It is also associated with pregnancy complications, including recurrent fetal loss, pre-eclampsia, and intrauterine growth restriction.
 
  • While bleeding can occur in some cases of APLA syndrome, it is not a typical feature of the condition. In fact, APLA syndrome is primarily characterized by a prothrombotic (increased clotting) state rather than a bleeding disorder.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2749, 2750.

questions.text: The following statement about Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLAb) is false:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Single titer anticardiolipin is diagnostic 

Single titer anticardiolipin is not diagnostic for Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA syndrome). The diagnosis of APLA syndrome requires the presence of persistent antiphospholipid antibodies (such as anticardiolipin antibodies, lupus anticoagulant, or anti-beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies) on at least two occasions, at least 12 weeks apart.

The other options are true:
     2.  APLA syndrome commonly presents with recurrent fetal loss, which is one of the hallmark features of the  condition.
  1. APLA syndrome may cause pulmonary hypertension as a result of thrombotic events in the pulmonary arteries.
  2. Warfarin is often used as a treatment for APLA syndrome, particularly in patients with thrombotic events, to prevent further clot formation. Other anticoagulant medications may also be used depending on the individual's specific situation.



 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2750.

questions.text: Low calcium and high phosphate are observed in the case of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Primary Hypoparathyroidism
 
  • Hypoparathyroidism is a condition characterized by insufficient production or secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands.PTH plays a crucial role in regulating calcium and phosphate levels in the body.
  • In hypoparathyroidism, the low or absent levels of PTH result in decreased calcium reabsorption from the kidneys and reduced release of calcium from bones.
  • As a result, blood calcium levels tend to be low (hypocalcemia), while phosphate levels in the blood tend to be high (hyperphosphatemia).
 
  • Hyperparathyroidism, on the other hand, is characterized by excessive production of PTH by the parathyroid glands. In this condition, blood calcium levels tend to be high (hypercalcemia), and phosphate levels may be normal or low.
  • Hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid) and hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid) primarily affect thyroid hormone levels and do not directly cause low calcium and high phosphate levels.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3163, 3185-3187.

questions.text: The following statement about pseudohypoparathyroidism is false:
questions.solution:
1. Decrease serum PTH  is the False statement about pseudohypoparathyroidism.

PSEUDOHYPOPARATHYROIDISM
 
  • PHP refers to a group of distinct inherited disorders. Patients affected by PHP type Ia (PHP1A) develop symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia in association with distinctive skeletal and developmental defects, referred to as Albright’s hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO). The hypocalcemia is due to a deficient PTH response in the proximal renal tubules.
​​​​​​​
  • Patients affected by PHP type Ib (PHP1B) also present with hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia but less frequently with obvious AHO features.
​​​​​​​
  • In response to the hypocalcemia observed in either disorder, PTH levels increase, leading to parathyroid hyperplasia and, in some cases, to autonomous PTH secretion.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3188, 3189.

questions.text: A patient reports hypoglycemia-related symptoms. Investigations show elevated insulin levels and lowered blood glucose. The results of the C-peptide assay indicate normal levels of C-peptide. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Accidental exogenous insulin administration
 
  • Elevated insulin levels and lowered blood glucose indicate the presence of exogenous insulin in the body.
  • C-peptide levels, which reflect endogenous insulin production, are normal.
  • This scenario suggests that the patient has inadvertently received additional insulin, leading to hypoglycemia-related symptoms.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3132, 3133.

questions.text: Select the condition that is associated with peripheral artery disease, coronary heart disease and stroke.
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Insulin deficiency
 
  • All the above complications are seen in Diabetes mellitus which is characterised by either Insulin deficiency (Type 1 DM) or Insulin resistance (Type 2 DM)
 
  • Type 1 DM is the result of interactions of genetic, environmental, and immunologic factors that ultimately lead to immune-mediated destruction of the pancreatic beta cells and insulin deficiency.

Macrovascular complications of Diabetes include:
  1. Coronary heart disease
  2. Peripheral arterial disease
  3. Cerebrovascular disease


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3099, 3120.

choices.text: Pseudohyponatremia is associated with low plasma osmolality
Hyponatremia associated with hyperglycemia has high plasma osmolality

questions.text: The following statement about hyponatremia is false:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Pseudohyponatremia is associated with low plasma osmolality 

Pseudohyponatremia refers to a laboratory artifact where the measured sodium level appears low due to an abnormal distribution of plasma water, typically caused by high lipid or protein content in the blood. However, the plasma osmolality remains normal in pseudohyponatremia. Therefore, statement 1 is false.
 
  • Statement 2 is true. Hyponatremia associated with hyperglycemia can occur in conditions like diabetic ketoacidosis, where the high glucose levels draw water into the extracellular space, leading to dilutional hyponatremia. In this case, the plasma osmolality is high.
  • Statement 3 is true. Hyponatremia associated with syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is characterized by excessive retention of water, leading to dilutional hyponatremia. It typically occurs in normovolemic or hypervolemic states.
  • Statement 4 is true. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can enhance the effects of vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone), leading to increased water reabsorption in the kidneys and potential development of hyponatremia.
 
  1. Hyponatremia:
    • Hypovolemic hyponatremia: Decreased sodium, decreased extracellular fluid volume, increased urine osmolality.
    • Euvolemic hyponatremia (e.g., SIADH): Decreased sodium, normal extracellular fluid volume, increased urine osmolality.
    • Hypervolemic hyponatremia (e.g., heart failure): Decreased sodium, increased extracellular fluid volume, decreased urine osmolality.
    • Hyponatremia associated with hyperglycemia (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis): Decreased sodium, normal or increased extracellular fluid volume, increased plasma osmolality.
  2. Pseudohyponatremia:
    • Pseudohyponatremia due to hyperlipidemia: Decreased measured sodium, normal plasma osmolality.
    • Pseudohyponatremia due to hyperproteinemia: Decreased measured sodium, normal plasma osmolality:





Note: In pseudohyponatremia, the measured sodium level is decreased, but the true sodium concentration is normal.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 341-343.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with dementia, incontinence, and ataxia. It is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Normal pressure hydrocephalus 
 
  • Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus(NPH) is a condition characterized by the accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the brain's ventricles, leading to enlarged ventricles and increased intracranial pressure.
 
  • The classic triad of symptoms in NPH includes gait disturbance (ataxia), cognitive decline (dementia), and urinary incontinence. "Wet, wacky, wobbly" is a phrase commonly used to describe the classic triad of symptoms
 
  • While Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease are common causes of dementia, they do not typically present with the combination of incontinence and ataxia as seen in NPH.

Steel Richardson syndrome, also known as progressive supranuclear palsy, primarily presents with motor symptoms and is not associated with incontinence.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 175, 194.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with acute left upper limb weakness, mitral stenosis, and atrial fibrillation. The weakness subsided completely in two weeks. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of Acute ischemic stroke (AIS) due to cardioembolism from cardiac thrombus in a case of Atrial fibrillation.
 
  • Cardioembolism is responsible for ~20% of all ischemic strokes. Stroke caused by heart disease is primarily due to embolism of thrombotic material forming on the atrial or ventricular wall or the left heart valves. These thrombi then detach and embolize into the arterial circulation. The thrombus may fragment or lyse quickly, producing only a TIA. Alternatively, the arterial occlusion may last longer, producing stroke.
 
  • Atrial fibrillation is the most common cause of cardioembolic AIS.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3339, 3340

questions.text: A 25-year-old develops focal seizures and a sudden onset of fever. The frontal lobe and temporal lobe of the brain are enhanced and hyperintense in the MRI image. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Herpes simplex encephalitis
 
  • Herpes simplex encephalitis (HSE) is a viral infection of the brain caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV).
  • It typically presents with focal neurological symptoms, such as seizures, altered mental status, and fever.
  • The involvement of the frontal and temporal lobes is characteristic of HSE and can be observed in MRI imaging as enhanced and hyperintense regions.
  • IOC- PCR of CSF for HSV 
 
  • Meningococcal meningitis (option 1) is a bacterial infection caused by Neisseria meningitidis and primarily affects the meninges. While it can cause neurological symptoms, the MRI findings described in the scenario are not typically associated with this condition.
  • Japanese encephalitis (option 3) is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes and primarily affects the brain. However, the MRI findings mentioned in the scenario are not consistent with Japanese encephalitis.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV, option 4) is a common viral infection that can affect various organs, including the brain. However, the specific MRI findings described in the scenario are not commonly associated with CMV encephalitis.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1095, 1096.

questions.text: Damage to the brain caused by a head injury in a patient is made worse by
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Hyperglycemia 
 
  • Hyperglycemia, can exacerbate brain damage caused by a head injury.
  • Elevated blood glucose levels can lead to increased inflammation, oxidative stress, and cell death in the brain.
  • It can also impair the brain's ability to regulate cerebral blood flow and worsen cerebral edema (swelling).
  • Hyperglycemia is associated with poorer outcomes and increased mortality in patients with traumatic brain injury.
 
  • Hypothermia (Option 2) is actually used as a therapeutic intervention in some cases of severe head injury to reduce brain metabolism and protect against further damage.
  • Hypocapnia (Option 3), or low levels of carbon dioxide in the blood, can cause cerebral vasoconstriction and decrease cerebral blood flow, potentially leading to ischemia and further brain injury. However, it is not a major factor in worsening brain damage compared to hyperglycemia.
  • Serum osmolality (Option 4) refers to the concentration of solutes in the blood. While severe disturbances in serum osmolality can have adverse effects on brain function, it is not directly implicated in worsening brain damage caused by a head injury.

TBI- Exacerbating and relieving factors:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3456-3458.

questions.text: Males with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism are all of the following, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, Kallman's syndrome (option 3) is a cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism while Viral orchitis, Klinefelter's syndrome and Noonan are causes of Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism. Kallman syndrome has also anosmia. 

Causes of Hypogonadism: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3014, 3020.

questions.text: The most typical reason for male hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, only Kallman's syndrome (option 3) is a cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leading to delayed puberty. It also has anosmia. 

Viral orchitis, Klinefelter's syndrome and Radiotherapy to testis are causes of Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism. (Elevated LH/FSH, low Sex hormones).





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3014, 3020.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the Motor Neuron Disease lesion site?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Anterior Horn cells 

The lesion site associated with MND is primarily the anterior horn cells. These cells are responsible for transmitting motor signals from the central nervous system to the skeletal muscles.
 Spinothalamic and spinocerebellar tracts are sensory tracts and therefore unrelated to MND.

      

 

Reference- Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition 165

questions.text: The following statement about Guillain Barre Syndrome (GBS) is false:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Sensory level
 
  • Guillain-Barre Syndrome typically presents with ascending paralysis, starting from the lower extremities and progressing upwards. It is characterized by flaccid paralysis, meaning there is loss of muscle tone and weakness.
  • Sensory symptoms such as paresthesias (abnormal sensations) and numbness can also occur in GBS.
  • Additionally, GBS is associated with a characteristic CSF laboratory finding known as albumino cytological dissociation, which refers to elevated protein levels in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) without a corresponding increase in white blood cell count.
  • But there is NO sensory level in GBS


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3501-3503.

questions.text: Kayser-Fleischer rings (KF rings) can be observed in:
questions.solution:
KF rings are brownish-yellow discolorations seen in the limbic zone of the cornea and occur due to copper deposition in Descemet's membrane. 
Amongst the given options, KF rings are characteristically seen in Wilson's disease. 

 



Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3236.

questions.text: Lord's plication is done to treat:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Hydrocele
  • Lord's plication is a surgical technique used to treat hydrocele.
  • It involves the excision of excess hydrocele sac and plication (folding) of the remaining sac to reduce its size and prevent re-accumulation of fluid.
  • Surgery is rarely indicated before 2 years because a majority resolve.
  • Teenage boys may have a non-communicating hydrocele with fluid arising from the tunica vaginalis; a plication (Lord’s procedure) or excision/eversion of the tunica vaginalis (Jaboulay procedure) are needed.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 257.

questions.text: Anuria and stomach discomfort are present in a 50-year-old female patient. According to radiological examinations, the patient had hydronephrosis and bilaterally impacted ureteric stones. RBCs with pus cells were discovered in the urine after investigation. What should be the first line of treatment if the serum creatinine level was 16 mg/dl and the urea level was 200 mmol/l?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 'J' stent drainage
  • Hydronephrosis with any size of ureteric stone: JJ stent is a suitable option.
  • JJ stent helps relieve obstruction and promote urine flow.
  • Percutaneous nephrostomy and ureteric stent are alternative options.
  • The JJ stent is a flexible tube inserted into the ureter to bypass the obstruction caused by the stone and allow urine to flow from the kidney to the bladder.

Fig: J stent insitu

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 281.

questions.text: What potential complications could there be if PCNL is performed through the eleventh intercostal space?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hydrothorax 
 
  • Hydrothorax is a potential complication that can occur when performing PCNL through the eleventh intercostal space.
  • Hydrothorax refers to the accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity, which can result from leakage of urine or irrigation fluid used during the procedure into the thoracic cavity.
  • It can lead to respiratory compromise and compression of the lungs, requiring appropriate management, such as thoracentesis or chest tube placement.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 2078.

questions.text: Which of the following stones can't be easily broken by ESWL?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Calcium oxalate monohydrate
ESWL (extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy) is a non-invasive procedure used to break down kidney stones into smaller fragments using shock waves.
  • Calcium oxalate monohydrate stones are the most challenging to break using ESWL.
  • Calcium oxalate monohydrate stones have a crystalline structure that makes them resistant to shock wave fragmentation.
  • On the other hand, calcium oxalate dihydrate, uric acid, and struvite stones are relatively easier to break using ESWL due to their composition and structure.
  • ESWL may still be attempted for calcium oxalate monohydrate stones, but alternative treatment options like ureteroscopic removal or percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) may be considered if ESWL fails to effectively break down the stones.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1471.

questions.text: Which of the following renal vascular anomalies occurs most frequently?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Supernumerary renal arteries 
 
  • Supernumerary renal arteries are the most frequently encountered renal vascular anomaly.
  • They refer to additional arteries originating from the abdominal aorta and supplying the kidneys in addition to the normal renal arteries.
  • Recognition of these vascular anomalies is crucial for surgical procedures involving the kidneys to ensure adequate blood supply and minimize the risk of inadvertent injury to these vessels.

Other options:
 
  • B. Supernumerary renal veins: This refers to the presence of additional veins draining the kidneys.
  • C. Double renal arteries: This is the presence of two separate arteries supplying a single kidney.
  • Double renal veins: This refers to the presence of two separate veins draining a single kidney.
They all occur less frequently compared to supernumerary renal arteries.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 2068.

questions.text: The first autologous kidney transplant was performed by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hardy
 
  • Renal auto-transplantation was first performed by James Hardy in 1963 to repair a high ureteral injury.


Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 357.

questions.text: The ideal time period to operate on an undescended testis is before:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 12 months of age
  • Surgical intervention for an undescended testis is ideally performed before the child reaches 12 months of age.
  • Orchidopexy is the treatment of choice for incompletely palpable unilateral undescended testis. Orchidopexy is usually performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age.
  • Delayed or untreated undescended testis can lead to various complications: Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication) Torsion Seminoma (Increased risk) Epididymorchitis Trauma (Increased risk) Sterility.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 258.

questions.text: The Gray-hack shunt can be found between:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Corpora cavernosa and saphenous vein 
 
  • The Gray-hack shunt is a surgical procedure used for the treatment of priapism, a persistent penile erection unrelated to sexual arousal.
  • The shunt involves creating a connection between the corpora cavernosa (cylindrical chambers in the penis) and the saphenous vein.
  • This connection allows the excessive blood trapped in the corpora cavernosa to drain out, relieving the prolonged erection.
  • The shunt is typically created by anastomosing the corpora cavernosa to the saphenous vein using surgical techniques.
Reference: van der Horst, Christof & Stuebinger, Henrik & Seif, Christoph & Melchior, Diethild & Martínez-Portillo, F.J. & Juenemann, Klaus-Peter. (2003). Priapism: Etiology, pathophysiology and management. International braz j urol : official journal of the Brazilian Society of Urology. 29. 391-400. 10.1590/S1677-55382003000500002.

questions.text: Which is the most common site of urethral carcinoma in men?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Bulbomembranous urethra 
 
  • The bulbomembranous urethra (60%) is the most common site of urethral carcinoma in men.
  • Urethral carcinoma typically presents with symptoms such as hematuria (blood in the urine), obstructive voiding, and urinary tract infections.
  • Other sites of urethral carcinoma include the penile urethra (30%), prostatic urethra (10%), and fossa navicularis.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1766.

questions.text: Hematemesis and upper abdominal discomfort are reported by an adult. A growth near the stomach's pyloric antrum was discovered through endoscopy. The pyloric antrum was the site of growth on the CT scan, and there was no evidence of distant metastases, infiltration, or invasion. Neoplastic growth was seen during laparotomy to encompass the stomach's posterior wall and the pancreas, extending 6 cm up to the tail of the pancreas. What surgical treatment will be most suitable?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Partial gastrectomy + distal pancreatectomy
 
  • The most suitable surgical treatment in this case would be option C, which involves performing a partial gastrectomy and distal pancreatectomy.
  • Given the neoplastic growth involving the stomach's posterior wall and extending up to the tail of the pancreas, this approach would ensure adequate resection of the tumor while preserving as much organ function as possible.
  • The addition of a splenectomy (option D) may be considered if there is involvement of the spleen or suspicion of metastasis, but it is not mentioned in the given scenario.
  • Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following: Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail Tumors of size >2 cm Tumors located within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1284.

choices.text: Small intestine and appendix account for almost 60% of all gastrointestinal carcinoid
5 year survival for carcinoid tumors is >60%
Appendiceal carcinoids are more common in females than males

questions.text: The following statement about Gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors is false:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Rectum is usually spared 
 
  • Gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors can occur in various parts of the gastrointestinal tract, including the small intestine, appendix, rectum, and other locations.
  • The statement is false because the rectum is not usually spared in gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors.
  • Rectal involvement can occur in carcinoid tumors, although the small intestine and appendix account for a higher percentage of these tumors.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 910.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for annular pancreas in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Duodenoduodenostomy  
 
  • Annular pancreas is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal stenosis or atresia.
  • It occurs because of the failure of a complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud during development, so a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum.
  • Duodenal obstruction typically causes vomiting in the neonate.
  • Treatment is duodenoduodenostomy, which involves creating a connection between two segments of the duodenum to bypass the obstruction caused by the annular pancreas.
  • Annular pancreas is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal atresia or stenosis and is therefore more prevalent in children with Down syndrome.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1267.

questions.text: Since three months ago, a woman has experienced repeated bouts of giddiness and stomach pain. The endoscopy went well. Her insulin levels were high, and her fasting blood glucose level was 40 mg%. There were no other abdominal findings on the CT abdomen, only a well-defined 8 mm enhancing lesion at the head of the pancreas. What course of action should be taken with this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Enucleation 
 
  • The presence of an 8 mm enhancing lesion at the head of the pancreas in a patient with high insulin levels and low blood glucose suggests an insulinoma, which is a neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas. Whipples triad is seen. 
  • Insulinomas having diameter of <2 cm without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign. Tumor enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas.
* Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following:
  • Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail
  • Tumors of size >2 cm
  • Tumors located within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1481.

questions.text: Complete rectal prolapse has been reported by a young male patient. The ideal procedure is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Abdominal rectopexy
 
  • Abdominal rectopexy is considered the ideal procedure for complete rectal prolapse.
  • Abdominal rectopexy involves securing the rectum to the sacrum, providing support and preventing further prolapse.
  • Delorme's procedure (option B) is a technique used for partial rectal prolapse.
  • Anterior resection (option C) is typically performed for conditions such as rectal cancer, not for rectal prolapse.
  • Goodsall's procedure (option D) refers to a technique used in the treatment of anal fistulas.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1400.

questions.text: The term "cystic blow out" is classified as follows under the Bismuth/Strasberg classification:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Type A
  • The Bismuth/Strasberg classification is used for bile duct injuries.
  • "Cystic blowout" refers to a bile duct injury involving the cystic duct.
  • It is classified as Type A according to the Bismuth/Strasberg classification.

Fig: Bismuth–Corlette classification of cholangiocarcinoma

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1257.

choices.text: Donor bile duct with recipient bile duct or Roux-en-Y choledochojejunostomy
Donor bile duct with duodenum of recipient
Donor bile duct with jejunum of receipt
External drainage for few days followed by choledochojejunostomy

questions.text: Which method for obtaining bile drainage in the donor liver during orthotropic liver transplantation is ideal?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Donor bile duct with recipient bile duct or Roux-en-Y choledochojejunostomy 
 
  • The ideal method for bile drainage in the donor liver during orthotopic liver transplantation is to connect the donor bile duct with the recipient bile duct or perform a Roux-en-Y choledochojejunostomy.
  • This allows for the drainage of bile from the donor liver into the recipient's intestine, maintaining biliary continuity.
  • Donor bile duct with the duodenum of the recipient (option B) or jejunum of the recipient (option C) are not the preferred methods.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1610.

questions.text: The most typical spleen cysts are:
questions.solution:
The most typical spleen cysts are hydatid cysts, which are caused by the larvae of the Echinococcus tapeworm.
Primary hydatid cysts most commonly occur in the liver.
Most patients are asymptomatic but when symptomatic, the patient presents with hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice Dermatoid cysts (option B), pseudocysts (option C), and lymphangiomas (option D) can also occur in the spleen but are less common.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 73.

questions.text: Primary restrictive procedures for morbid obesity include all of the following, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Switch duodenal operations 
 
  • Primary restrictive procedures for morbid obesity include vertical band gastroplasty (option A), Roux-en-Y operation (option C), and laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding (option D).
  • Switch duodenal operations (option B), such as duodenal switch or biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch, are primarily malabsorptive procedures rather than restrictive procedures.
* Types of bariatric surgery:



Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1189.

questions.text: The score for trauma and injury severity (TRISS includes):
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: RTS + ISS + Age
 
  • The trauma and injury severity score (TRISS) is a method used to predict trauma patient outcomes.
  • It includes the Revised Trauma Score (RTS), Injury Severity Score (ISS), and Age as components.
  • Option B (RTS + ISS + Age) correctly represents the components of the TRISS score.



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 389.

questions.text: Six hours after an RTA, a 27-year-old patient arrived at the emergency room complaining of left-sided stomach pain. He had steady hemodynamics and tested positive for FAST. Grade III splenic laceration was discovered by contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) imaging. What medical procedure is most suitable?
questions.solution:
Hemodynamically stable grade 1 to 3 injuries are managed conservatively.

Non-operative Management
  • When facilities are available, splenic injury can be managed conservatively by non-operative management (NOM). 80% of blunt splenic injuries can be managed non-operatively (success is more in children).
  • Clinically close observation, serial haematocrit evaluationand serial CT abdomen/US abdomen at regular intervals to assess the progress or regress of the bleeding spleen has to be done.
    It is often supported by angiographic selective embolisation using gelfoam,coils and stents to improve the splenic salvage rate.
    But it may cause pain, splenic abscess or infarction. Indications for non-operative treatment: (1) Only splenic injury-no other associated injuries. (2) Grade I, II and Ill injuries. (3) Haemodynamically stable patient
  • Absolute bed rest (for 2- 3 weeks), sedation(initially), antibiotic coverage and proper monitoring are needed.

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 663.

questions.text: Six hours after an RTA, a 27-year-old patient arrives at the emergency room complaining of left-sided stomach pain. He had steady hemodynamics and tested positive for FAST. A grade III laceration and contrast flush are visible on a CECT scan. What type of management will be most effective?
questions.solution:
Contrast blush on CECT indicates active hemorrhage. A patient with stable hemodynamics should undergo endovascular intervention and embolisation should be attempted.

Non-operative Management
  • When facilities are available, splenic injury can be managed conservatively by non-operative management (NOM). 80% of blunt splenic injuries can be managed non-operatively (success is more in children).
  • Clinically close observation, serial haematocrit evaluation and serial CT abdomen/US abdomen at regular intervals to assess the progress or regress of the bleeding spleen has to be done.
  • Absolute bed rest (for 2- 3 weeks), sedation(initially), antibiotic coverage and proper monitoring are needed.
  • It is often supported by angiographic selective embolisation using gelfoam,coils and stents to improve the splenic salvage rate. But it may cause pain, splenic abscess or infarction.
  • Indications for non-operative treatment: (1) Only splenic injury-no other associated injuries. (2) Grade I, II and Ill injuries. (3) Haemodynamically stable patient.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 663.

choices.text: Injury to the left lobe to the diaphragm

questions.text: A woman with a stab wound to the left side of her abdomen visited the emergency room. She had stable hemodynamics, and a contrast-enhanced CT scan showed that her spleen had been lacerated. The patient was scheduled for a laparoscopy, but as soon as the pneumoperitoneum was formed, the patient's pO2 abruptly fell. What is the most probable reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Gaseous embolism through splenic vessels 
 
  • The abrupt fall in pO2 after pneumoperitoneum formation suggests a gaseous embolism.
  • When performing laparoscopy, creating a pneumoperitoneum involves insufflating carbon dioxide gas into the abdominal cavity.
  • While rare, a potential complication is the entry of gas into blood vessels, resulting in a gaseous embolism.
  • In this case, if carbon dioxide gas entered the splenic vessels, it could lead to a sudden decrease in pO2 as the embolism obstructs the flow of oxygenated blood.
This can cause a significant drop in oxygen levels.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1620.

questions.text: A patient says they've had a fever for three weeks. He is discovered to have splenomegaly upon evaluation. A hypoechoic shadow is visible on ultrasonography in the spleen close to the hilum. In blood culture, gram-negative bacteria are isolated. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Salmonella 

The clinical presentation of fever, splenomegaly, and a hypoechoic shadow in the spleen close to the hilum suggests the possibility of splenic abscess.
In cases of splenic abscess, gram-negative bacteria, especially Salmonella, are commonly isolated.

Causes of splenic abscess:
  • Infected splenic embolus, in association with typhoid and paratyphoid fever,
  • osteomyelitis,
  • otitis media
  • puerperal sepsis,
  • pancreatic necrosis
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1538.

questions.text: A splenectomy is being scheduled for a patient with ITP who has a platelet count of 50,000. When is the ideal time to administer platelets to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: After ligating the splenic artery 
 
  • In patients with ITP (immune thrombocytopenic purpura) undergoing splenectomy, administering platelets after ligating the splenic artery is the ideal timing.
  • Ligation of the splenic artery results in the isolation of the spleen from the circulation, reducing the risk of platelet sequestration and destruction, and maximizing platelet survival.
  • Administering platelets before surgery (options A and B) may result in rapid consumption and inadequate platelet count during the surgical procedure.
  • Administering platelets immediately after removal of the spleen (option D) is not as effective in preventing platelet sequestration and destruction during the surgical manipulation.
Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1535.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of abdominal Aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Atherosclerosis 
 
  • Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).
  • AAA is the dilation and weakening of the abdominal aorta, the main blood vessel supplying blood to the abdomen and lower extremities.
  • Atherosclerosis, a condition characterized by the buildup of plaque in the arterial walls, increases the risk of AAA formation.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 506.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent techniques of grading is used to assess the prognosis or outcome following a subarachnoid hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Hess and hunt scale  
 
  • The Hess and Hunt scale is a grading system used to assess the prognosis or outcome following a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).
  • It evaluates the severity of SAH based on the patient's clinical presentation and the amount of blood observed on imaging studies, such as computed tomography (CT) scans.
  • The scale ranges from grade 0 to grade 5, with higher grades indicating a worse prognosis.
  • This scale helps in predicting the risk of complications and guiding the management of SAH patients.


Here's a summary table of commonly used scales in emergency medicine scenarios:






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354.

questions.text: All of the following will have a negative impact on a child's health status before the age of five, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Maternal Hb of 11 gm% 

Factors affecting a child's health status before age five:
  • Malnutrition (poor growth, developmental delays, and increased susceptibility to infections in children).
  • Low birth weight (increases the risk of developmental challenges during early childhood).
  • Infections ( such as respiratory and diarrheal diseases, can lead to severe health issues in young children.
Maternal hemoglobin (Hb) level of 11 gm% does not have a negative impact on a child's health status before age five.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 598, 599.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl with no symptoms is discovered to have persistent hypertension. There is no noteworthy past, and a urine test results in normal results. Which among the following is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Option 2 is the correct option.
  • Renal parenchymal disease, is the most likely cause of persistent hypertension in a 7-year-old girl with no symptoms and normal urine test results.
  • Renal parenchymal disease refers to damage to the functional tissue of the kidneys, which can lead to hypertension. This type of kidney disease can be caused by a number of factors, including congenital abnormalities, infections, and autoimmune disorders.
  • Essential hypertension (option 1) is rare in children(unlike adults) and is usually diagnosed only after other causes of hypertension have been ruled out.
  • Polycystic kidney disease (option 3) is a genetic disorder that causes the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure. However, this condition is rare in young children.
  • Coarctation of the aorta (option 4) is a narrowing of the aorta, which can cause high blood pressure in the arms and head and low blood pressure in the legs. However, this condition typically presents with other symptoms such as leg cramps, cold feet, and weak or absent pulses, which are not mentioned in the question stem.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2492

questions.text: A child is experiencing sporadic episodes of left flank pain. Ultrasonography shows a normal ureter and a dilated renal pelvis with cortical thinning. A 19% difference in kidney function was found. Among the following, which type of management is best:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Pyeloplasty 

The presentation of normal ureter and a dilated renal pelvis is suggestive of PUJ obstruction. Anderson Hynes pyeloplasty is the treatment of choice for it.

Nephrectomy is done if the function of the obstructed kidney is less than 10%.






 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 501

questions.text: A newborn has a fever, lethargy, distension in the abdomen, vomiting, and constipation. Clinically, he was identified as having a possible perforation and volvulus neonatorum. Best imaging modality would be:
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 1: Plain X-ray to see free gas under diaphragm. 
  • Option 2 and 4 : Barium enema and barium meal follow through are contraindicated in a case of suspected perforation as barium causes chemical peritonitis.
  • Option 3: Upper GI endoscopy also cannot be done as an endoscope itself may cause more perforations. Hence, in a case of volvulus neonatorum, plain X-ray abdomen standing becomes the best option among the ones given.
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 1953

questions.text: A ten-year-old child with seizures arrives at the pediatric emergency room. The upper extremity's blood pressure was recorded as 200/140 mm hg. There were no discernible femoral pulses. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Coarctation of the Aorta 

Hypertension in upper limb with absent femoral pulses in a child are suggestive of coarctation of aorta.

Option 1 – Takayasu aortoarteritis is a medium vessel disease affecting middle aged individuals of 40-50 age group.

Option 2 – renal parenchymal disease will present with features of edema, ascitis, hypertension, hematuria and reduced urine output. Femoral pulses will be present normally.

Option 3 – Grand mal seizures will only present with tonic clonic seizures affecting the whole body. Hypertension may be present but brachio-femoral BP difference is unlikely.

Some points about Coarctation of aorta
  • Obstructive lesion
  • Location : junction of arch and descending aorta
  • Clinical features :
  1. Intermittent claudication
  2. Feeble femoral pulse
  3. Radio femoral delay
  4. Hypertension
  5. Complete narrowing in neonates leads to shock
  6. Renal damage
  • Diagnosis – X-ray (inferior rib notching and 3 sign )
  • Management – angioplasty followed by balloon dilatation




Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 428,429

questions.text: A young patient arrives with hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly. Even after epinephrine injection, blood sugar levels do not improve. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Von Gierke's disease Von Gierke’s disease is characterized by absence of glucose-6-phosphate. Normally, administration of intravenous epinephrine results in glycogenolysis via stimulation of glucose-6-phosphatase which is the rate limiting enzyme of the metabolic pathway. This is known as IV epinephrine challenge test. However, in Von Gierke’s disease, this phenomenon does not occur in well fed state as well as fasting state owing to deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase. IV epinephrine challenge test is primarily used to differentiate Von Gierke’s disease from Cori’s In Cori’s disease which occurs due to deficiency of debranching enzyme, some amount of glucose synthesis occurs via breakdown of glycogen by glycogen phosphorylase. This combined with dietary glucose leads to surge in blood glucose levels in well-fed state. However, during overnight fasting, this does not occur due to ineffective glycogenolysis.
Type Name Deficient Enzyme Key Specific Features
Type I Von Gierke Disease Glucose-6-phosphatase Severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis
Type II Pompe Disease Lysosomal acid α-glucosidase Cardiomegaly, muscle weakness, "floppy baby" (infantile form)
Type III Cori Disease Debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase) Milder hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, accumulation of limit dextrin
Type IV Andersen Disease Branching enzyme Hepatosplenomegaly, liver cirrhosis, early death
Type V McArdle Disease Muscle glycogen phosphorylase Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria (red urine)
Type VI Hers Disease Liver glycogen phosphorylase Mild fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 174.

questions.text: The likelihood of developing epilepsy following febrile convulsions is significantly increased by all of the following, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Early age of onset (age <1 year) is a risk factor for recurrence of febrile seizures, NOT Late age of onset.

The other risk factors for such recurrences are as follows:

Major:
  • Age <1 yr
  • Duration of fever <24 hours
  • Fever 38-39°C

Minor:
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Male gender
  • Lower serum sodium at the time of presentation



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 3092, 3093.

questions.text: Several times per day, a youngster has brief moments of vacant staring. The youngster is unresponsive during the entire vacant episode, which starts out abruptly. The youngster is otherwise normal, and there is no history of aura or postictal disorientation to go along with it. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Absence seizures 

Absence seizures, also known as petit mal seizures, are a type of generalized seizure characterized by brief episodes of vacant staring and unresponsiveness. These episodes can occur multiple times per day and typically last for a few seconds. The onset of absence seizures is abrupt, and the child may appear to be "daydreaming" during the episode.

Key features of absence seizures include:
 
  • Brief duration: Episodes typically last for a few seconds and resolve spontaneously.
  • Vacant staring: The child appears to be inattentive and unresponsive during the episode, often with a blank facial expression.
  • Abrupt onset and termination: The episodes start and end suddenly, without any warning signs or postictal confusion/disorientation.
  • No aura or postictal period: Unlike other seizure types, absence seizures are not typically preceded by an aura (warning sign) or followed by a postictal period of confusion or disorientation.

Other options: 
 
  • Grand mal seizures (Option 1) are generalized tonic-clonic seizures characterized by loss of consciousness, muscle rigidity, and convulsions.
  • Complex partial seizures (Option 3) involve impaired consciousness with repetitive movements and may have associated aura or postictal confusion.
  • Daydreaming (Option 4) is a normal state of mind characterized by being lost in thoughts but does not involve altered consciousness or staring episodes.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3306, 3307.

  • Option 2 : arbovirus family transmits infection from mosquitoes, ticks or other arthropods to humans includes dengue, West Nile fever, Japanese encephalitis, eastern and western equine encephalitis.
  • Option 3 : HSV encephalitis is the most common cause of sporadic encephalitis in the world

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3232-3234

questions.text: A youngster was seen with 5,000 CPK value, positive Gower's sign, calf hypertrophy, and lower limb weakness. The following diagnosis is most likely:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Duchenne muscular dystrophy 
 
  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and wasting.
  • It primarily affects boys and typically presents in early childhood.
  • The clinical features described in the question, including elevated CPK levels, positive Gower's sign, calf hypertrophy, and lower limb weakness, are classic findings seen in DMD.

Other options:
 
  • Spinal muscular atrophy (Option 2) is a different neuromuscular disorder characterized by progressive degeneration of the spinal motor neurons, resulting in muscle weakness.
  • Myotonia congenita (Option 3) is a genetic disorder that leads to muscle stiffness and delayed relaxation after contraction.
  • Myotonic dystrophy (Option 4) is a multisystem disorder characterized by myotonia, muscle wasting, and involvement of various organs.







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3519-3521.

questions.text: A young youngster with a history of seizures and mental impairment arrives at the clinic. On clinical inspection, many hypopigmented macules are seen. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tuberous sclerosis 
 
  • Tuberous Sclerosis (Bourneville disease) is a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of benign tumors in various organs, including the brain, skin, kidneys, heart, and lungs.
 
  • It is commonly associated with seizures, intellectual disability, and developmental delays.
 
  • The hypopigmented macules, known as ash-leaf spots, are a characteristic feature of Tuberous Sclerosis and can be observed on the skin.Other clinical features may include facial angiofibromas, shagreen patches, and renal angiomyolipomas.

Other options: 
 
  • Neurofibromatosis (Option 2) is characterized by the development of neurofibromas and café-au-lait macules but is not typically associated with seizures and mental impairment.
  • Sturge-Weber Syndrome (Option 3) is characterized by facial port-wine stains and may cause neurological symptoms such as seizures, but it does not commonly present with hypopigmented macules.
  • Linear Epidermal Nevus Syndrome (Option 4) is characterized by linear epidermal nevi but is not typically associated with seizures and mental impairment.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 388.

questions.text: A woman who had an abortion six months ago is currently experiencing secondary amenorrhea. Her FSH levels were 6 mlU/ml. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Secondary Amenorrhea with normal FSH levels are suggestive of Uterine synechiae.
 
  • Aggressive uterine curettage during early pregnancy can damage the basal layer of the endometrium, leading to scarring and adhesions within the uterus. This scarring interferes with normal endometrial growth and shedding, resulting in secondary amenorrhea, as observed in this patient. These intrauterine adhesions are referred to as uterine synechiae or Asherman syndrome.
  • In Asherman syndrome, there is no disruption of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, so follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels remain within the normal range, typically between 4 and 25 IU/L, as seen in this patient.
  • In contrast, with pituitary dysfunction, FSH levels are usually decreased. In cases of ovarian dysfunction, the loss of negative feedback from ovarian hormones (such as estrogen) on the pituitary and hypothalamus leads to increased FSH levels, often rising above 25 IU/L
  • Asherman syndrome is characterized by a range of intrauterine scarring, which can include thin adhesions, dense bands, or complete obliteration of the uterine cavity. This condition typically results from endometrial damage following aggressive curettage, often related to miscarriage or elective abortion. It can also arise from other uterine surgeries, such as myomectomy or cesarean delivery, or from infections associated with intrauterine devices.
  • Patients with Asherman syndrome may present with amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss due to inadequate placentation, depending on the extent of the scarring.
  • On hysterosalpingography (HSG) or saline-infusion sonography, Asherman syndrome is identified by multiple filling defects. However, a definitive diagnosis is made through hysteroscopy. The preferred surgical treatment for the syndrome is hysteroscopic lysis of adhesions.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 153, 154. 
Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 374, 375.

questions.text: Which of the following is most frequently linked to cervical cancer?

questions.text: A complex total abdominal hysterectomy was performed on a 52-year-old woman two weeks prior, and she now has persistent urine leakage and dysuria. Vesicovaginal fistula is suspected. The investigation of choice for making a diagnosis is:

questions.text: Which of the following best marker for having neural tube defects
questions.solution:
• NTD occurs due to failure of closure of the Neuropore.
  • Antenatal diagnosis of NTD is usually done by USG at 14-16 weeks of gestation. The earliest it can be done by USG is at 10-12 weeks.
  • Maternal serum markers can also be used for diagnosis While Acetylcholine esterase and Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) both indicate NTD, Acetylcholine esterase is the most specific and best marker.
  • Acetylcholinesterase is an enzyme that is primarily found in nerve tissue. In the case of neural tube defects, the protective layer around the neural tissue may be compromised, allowing AChE to leak into the amniotic fluid.
  • Detecting elevated levels of AChE in amniotic fluid can, therefore, be indicative of NTDs.

questions.text: Select the correct statement regarding 'multiple pregnancies':
questions.solution:
• The twin peak sign indicates the presence of a dichorionic-diamniotic twin gestation.
  • The twin peak represents the extension of placental villi into the potential space that is formed from the reflection of apposed amniotic and chorionic layers from each fetus.

 
  • Fetuses of same gender excludes dichorionicity – This is not true. Same-gender fetuses can still be dichorionic if they result from the splitting of a single zygote (monozygotic twins) or if they are dizygotic twins.
  • Thick separating membrane is a feature of monochorionic twins – Monochorionic twins share a chorion, and the separating membrane, if present, is typically thinner compared to dichorionic twins.
  • Chorionicity can be reliably detected only after 16 weeks of gestation – Chorionicity is best detected early, particularly in the first trimester (before 14 weeks)



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 842.

questions.text: What is the CDC regimen to treat chlamydia infection in pregnancy
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Azithromycin
 
  • Untreated chlamydial infection has been linked to problems during pregnancy, including preterm labor, premature rupture of membranes, and low birth weight.
  • The newborn may also become infected during delivery as the baby passes through the birth canal.
  • Exposed newborns can develop eye and lung infections.
  • CDC Regimen for Chlamydial Infection During Pregnancy Azithromycin 1 g orally in a single dose. Alternative Regimen Amoxicillin 500 mg orally 3 times/day for 7 days
  • Doxycycline and tetracycline are contraindicated in Pregnancy as it can cause nasal hypoplasia in fetus. 



Reference: Sexually Transmitted Infections Treatment Guidelines 2021, CDC (2021). URL: https://www.cdc.gov/std/treatment-guidelines/chlamydia.htm
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 344.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice to treat chlamydia infection in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Erythromycin

Since Azithromycin and Amoxicillin are not in the option the other medicine that can be used to treat Chlamydia in pregnancy is Erythromycin.

  • Because of concerns regarding chlamydia persistence after exposure to penicillin-class antibiotics that has been demonstrated in animal and in vitro studies, amoxicillin is listed as an alternative therapy for C. trachomatis for pregnant women.
  • Erythromycin is no longer recommended because of the frequency of gastrointestinal side effects that can result in therapy nonadherence.
  • In addition, systematic reviews and meta-analyses have noted an association with macrolide antimicrobials, especially erythromycin, during pregnancy and adverse child outcomes, indicating cautious use in pregnancy.
  • Doxycycline and Tetracycline are contraindicated in pregnancy as they can cause nasal hypoplasia. 



Reference: Sexually Transmitted Infections Treatment Guidelines 2021, CDC (2021). URL: https://www.cdc.gov/std/treatment-guidelines/chlamydia.htm
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 344.

questions.text: Which of these causes non immune hydrops fetalis
questions.solution:
• Parvo virus B19 causes Non immune hydrops
  •  Hydrops fetalis is a serious condition characterized by abnormal accumulation of fluid in two or more fetal compartments, such as the abdominal cavity, pleural cavity, and skin.
  • Etiology: Common causes include Rh incompatibility, infections (like parvovirus B19 and toxoplasmosis), fetal anemia, cardiac defects, and chromosomal abnormalities.
  • Clinical Features: Signs may include fetal edema (swelling), polyhydramnios (excess amniotic fluid), and ultrasound findings such as thickened skin, ascites, or pleural effusion.

  • Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily through ultrasound imaging, which reveals the fluid accumulation

questions.text: At 32 weeks pregnant, a woman displays signs of a potential abortion. Which of the following statements regarding the use of antibiotics is false?
questions.solution:
Correct ans option 1- Antibiotic prophylaxis even in unruptured membranes.

In cases of unruptured membranes, there is no need of antibiotics prophylaxis.

Students should remember indications of intrapartum GBS prophylaxis


Indications for GBS Intrapartum Prophylaxis :
  • GBS bacteriuria during current pregnancy (no need for rectovaginal culture at 35 to 37 weeks of gestation) 
  • GBS status unknown within six weeks of delivery and any of the following:
  • Less than 37 weeks of gestation and cesarean delivery not planned 
  • Rupture of membranes 18 hours or more before delivery Maternal temperature of 38.0°C (100.4°F) or greater and no evidence of chorioamnionitis 
  • Positive maternal GBS culture at 35 to 37 weeks of gestation during current pregnancy 
  • Previous newborn with GBS-invasive disease



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 203, 651, 652.

questions.text: At 34 weeks of pregnancy, a woman experiences fluid leakage from her vaginum and meconium-colored liquor. The most likely cause amongst the following organisms:
questions.solution:
Listeria Monocytogenes

  • Listeriosis is a rare infection, but is about 20 times more common in pregnant women than in the general population.
  • Pregnant women account for 27% of all listerial infections which can cause mild illness in mothers, but can be devastating to the fetus, in some cases leading to severe disease or fetal death.
  • During the first trimester of pregnancy, listeriosis may cause miscarriage. As the pregnancy progresses to third trimester, the mother is more at risk.
  • Listeriosis can also lead to premature labor, the delivery of a low-birth-weight infant, or infant death
  • Listeria in newborns can be classified as early onset or late-onset infection. Meconium-stained amniotic fluid is common in newborns with early onset Listeria.
  • Respiratory difficulty is common, including a history of cyanotic episodes, rapid breathing, and grunting.
 



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 1196.
Online source https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/965841

The PMTCT Cascade

questions.text: A person who has worn contact lenses for a long time says that his left eye is irritated. After investigations, keratitis was determined to be the cause, and samples of the corneal tissue showed the proliferation of pseudomonas aeruginosa. The bacteria is found to be multi-drug resistant. Which of the following best describes how these isolated pseudomonas aeruginosa stains developed antibiotic resistance
questions.solution:
The most important mechanism by which pseudomonas causes infection and develops resistance is by its ability to produce a biofilm. It also has other virulence factors such as slime layer, presence of pili and production of exotoxin A.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 321.

questions.text: Endophthalmitis does not involve inflammation of:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Sclera.
 
  • Endophthalmitis is the inflammation of the inner coats of the eyeball (except sclera) due to intraocular colonization of infectious agents. 
  • There is exudation within intraocular fluids. It generally occurs after trauma, surgery, or due to an endogenous source. 
  • It is characterized by poor visual acuity, corneal edema, hypopyon, vitreous inflammation, and poor fundus visualization. 
  • The structures commonly affected in endophthalmitis include the uvea (iris, ciliary body, and choroid), retina, and vitreous.
  • The avascular densely packed collagenous matrix of the cornea and sclera serves as a potent barrier against infectious infiltration in normal eyes.
  • Hence, the sclera, which is the tough outer layer of the eye, is not typically involved in the inflammation seen in endophthalmitis.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 724.

questions.text: The least common corneal dystrophy is:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Macular dystrophy
 
  • Corneal dystrophies are a group of genetic disorders that affect the cornea, the transparent front part of the eye.
  • Macular dystrophy, also known as Groenouw type II dystrophy, is one of the rarest forms of corneal dystrophy.
  • Macular dystrophy primarily affects the central portion of the cornea, known as the macula, and is characterized by the presence of small, round opacities.
  • Compared to other corneal dystrophies, macular dystrophy is relatively uncommon, making it the least common among the options listed.


 Reference: Parsons, Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 187.

questions.text: Cherry red spot is not seen in:
Relative afferent papillary defect (RAPD) can be observed during damage to:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Optic nerve.
 
  • A relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), also known as a Marcus Gunn pupil, is an abnormal response of the pupil to light stimulation.
  • It is typically observed during damage or dysfunction of the optic nerve, specifically the optic nerve fibers carrying the afferent (incoming) visual signals.
  • When there is a lesion or damage to the optic nerve, the affected eye will exhibit a reduced or impaired response to light compared to the unaffected eye.
  • This results in a relative difference in the pupillary response when the light is shifted from one eye to the other (Swinging Flash Light Test). 
  • Unilateral optic nerve disease produces a relative afferent pupillary defect on the same side of the lesion.
  • However, Optic tract lesions tend to demonstrate a relative afferent pupillary defect in the contralateral eye.
As the side of lesion is not mentioned in the question, Therefore, the preferred answer should be Optic nerve > Optic tract.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no: 887, 918, 919, 922.

questions.text: When chewing, a patient with ptosis exhibits retraction of the ptotic eyelid. This points towards:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Marcus Gunn jaw winking syndrome.
 
  • Marcus Gunn jaw-winking syndrome or Marcus Gunn phenomenon or trigemino-oculomotor synkinesis: Condition characterized by abnormal synkinesis (involuntary simultaneous movement) between the jaw and eyelid.
  • In this syndrome, when the patient opens their mouth or chews, there is an elevation or retraction of the ptotic (drooping) eyelid on the same side.
  • The abnormal synkinesis between the jaw movement and eyelid elevation occurs due to miswiring or aberrant connections between the trigeminal (jaw) and oculomotor (eyelid) nerves.
  • This results in a phenomenon where jaw movement triggers an unintended eyelid movement.



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 397.

choices.text: Whole eye needs to be preserved in tissue culture
Specular microscopy analysis is used to assess endothelial cell count

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding corneal transplantation is true?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Specular microscopy analysis is used to assess endothelial cell count.
 
  • Specular microscopy analysis is used to assess endothelial cell count.
  • Specular microscopy is a non-invasive imaging technique used to visualize and analyze the corneal endothelium, which is the innermost layer of the cornea. 
  • It provides information about the endothelial cell density, morphology, and other parameters, which are crucial in evaluating the health of the cornea for transplantation.

Other options:
  • Option 1:  In corneal transplantation, only the cornea is transplanted, not the whole eye. The cornea can be preserved using various methods, such as organ culture or cold storage.
  • Option 2:  Donor corneas can be accepted even if the donor is older than 60 years.
  • Option 4: Unlike solid organ transplants (e.g., kidney, heart), cornea being an avascular structure corneal transplantation does not typically require strict HLA (human leukocyte antigen) matching between the donor and the recipient.

Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 297.
Parson’s diseases of the eye, 23rd edition, Page no 197.

questions.text: Arden Index is linked to the:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: EOG (Electrooculogram) 
  • The Arden Index is associated with the EOG (Electrooculogram).
  • During Electro-oculography (EOG), the patient is asked to alternately look towards two targets placed in front of him to the right and to the left, and the potentials recorded by the electrodes are printed. 
  • The potentials are continuously recorded for a fixed time interval in a light-adapted and dark-adapted state. 
  • The ratio of the light peak over the dark trough is known as the Arden index.
  • It is useful in diagnosing objectively the early stages of retinal diseases that affect the retinal pigment epithelium or in cases where the fundus cannot be clearly seen.

Arden Index Classification:






Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 540.

questions.text: A patient with a known mutation in the "Rb gene" has retinoblastoma but is otherwise healthy. Which of the following malignancies is the patient's greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Osteosarcoma 

The Rb gene (retinoblastoma gene), located in chromosome 13q14, is a tumor suppressor gene involved in regulating cell division and preventing the formation of tumors.
  • When there is a mutation or loss of function in the Rb gene, it increases the risk of developing retinoblastoma, a malignant tumor of the retina. There is a strong association between hereditary retinoblastoma and Rb gene mutations with an increased risk of osteosarcoma, particularly in the teenage and young adult years.
  • Carriers of this trait have a 10,000-fold increased risk of developing retinoblastoma (often in both eyes) compared with the general population and are at greatly increased risk of developing osteosarcoma and other soft tissue sarcomas.
While these options (1, 3 and 4) represent potential risks, osteosarcoma is generally considered the greatest risk for patients with Rb gene mutations.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 291.

questions.text: Vestibular Schwannoma most frequently starts at the:
questions.solution:

questions.text: Otoacoustic emissions begins at the:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: outer hair cells 

Otoacoustic emissions(OAE) begin at Outer Hair cells (OHC). OHCs are more prone to noise-induced trauma and ototoxicity. Hence, OAE is used to detect early noise-induced hearing loss, to differentiate between cochlear (OAE are present) and retro cochlear (OAE are absent) and to screen hearing in neonates as an objective test.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 29

questions.solution:

Other options
  • Option 1 -  The cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone is ithe most common site for spontaneous or traumatic CSF leaks due to its thin structure and proximity to the nasal cavity. 
  • Option 2 -  Beta-2 transferrin is a protein found almost exclusively in CSF (and to a lesser extent in vitreous humor and perilymph). Its detection in nasal or ear fluid is a highly specific for CSF Rhinorrhoea.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about 'Menisci' is inaccurate
questions.solution:
The inaccurate statement is: 1. Medial meniscus is more mobile than lateral

Explanation:
The lateral meniscus is more mobile than the medial meniscus due to its looser attachment to the tibia and absence of a strong connection to the joint capsule and medial collateral ligament (MCL).
The medial meniscus is more firmly attached to the tibia and MCL, making it less mobile and more prone to injury.

Other options

  1. Lateral meniscus covers more tibial articular surface than medial – The lateral meniscus is larger, more circular, and covers a greater portion of the tibial plateau.

  2. Medial meniscus is more commonly injured than lateral – Due to its firm attachment to the MCL and tibial plateau, the medial meniscus is less mobile and more susceptible to injury, especially in twisting injuries.

  3. Menisci are predominantly made up of type I collagen – Menisci are primarily composed of Type I collagen, which provides tensile strength, making this statement accurate.



Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no 254

choices.text: Total water content of cartilage is decreased

questions.text: Which of the following claims concerning articular cartilage changes with age is untrue
questions.solution:
• Enzymatic degradation of proteoglycans is not increased with age.
  • In fact, the opposite is true - the ability of chondrocytes to break down old proteoglycans decreases with age, leading to an accumulation of damaged molecules in the cartilage
  • Other statements are true

questions.text: One should avoid using metal on metal articulation in:
questions.solution:
Metal-on-metal (MoM) articulation is generally avoided in young females for several reasons:

1. Metal Ion Release: MoM implants can release metal ions, such as cobalt and chromium, into the bloodstream due to wear over time. These ions can accumulate in tissues, potentially causing local soft tissue reactions (metallosis), inflammation, and pseudotumor formation. In young females, the long-term exposure to these ions is a significant concern, particularly given their longer life expectancy.

2. Reproductive Health Concerns- There are concerns about the effect of metal ions on fertility and pregnancy. Elevated levels of metal ions in the bloodstream may pose a theoretical risk to a developing fetus. This is especially important in younger women who may still want to bear children.

3. Higher Failure Rates: MoM implants have shown higher revision rates due to mechanical wear, loosening, and tissue reactions compared to other bearing surfaces like ceramic or polyethylene. Given the younger patient’s activity level and longer life expectancy, the risk of implant failure becomes more significant.

4. Increased Risk of Adverse Reactions: MoM implants are associated with adverse local tissue reactions (ALTRs) and osteolysis (bone loss), which can complicate future revision surgeries. Young females are likely to outlive their implants, and having these complications can make future revisions more complex.

Because of these risks, other materials like ceramic-on-ceramic or ceramic-on-polyethylene are generally preferred for young female patients.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 341

questions.text: After a total hip replacement 1 month ago, the patient had sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath on the second postoperative day. Right ventricular enlargement and tricuspid regurgitation were detected by echocardiography. Which diagnosis is most likely
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis is pulmonary thromboembolism.
  • The risk of postoperative pulmonary embolism is highest during the first 5 weeks post surgery.
  • It is the most common cause of death following hip surgery due to prolonged immobilization.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 44

questions.text: The characteristics triad of Klippel-Feil syndrome does not include:
questions.solution:
• Klippel-Feil syndrome is a  disorder characterized by the fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae in the neck.
  • The fusion of these vertebrae can result in a short neck, limited neck movements, and a low hairline at the back of the head.
  • These three characteristics are known as the classic triad of Klippel-Feil syndrome
  • Elevated scapula, as it is not a part of the classic triad of Klippel-Feil syndrome.



Reference- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK493157/

questions.text: Which of the following vertebral abnormalities has the lowest likelihood of congenital scoliosis progression:
questions.solution:
• A block vertebra is a congenital vertebral anomaly where two adjacent vertebrae are fused together. This anomaly is considered the most stable type of vertebral anomaly, and it has the least likelihood of causing spinal deformity or scoliosis.
  • The reason for this is that the fused vertebrae do not allow for any motion, so they cannot contribute to the development of a spinal curve.
  • Hemivertebra, wedge vertebra, and unilateral unsegmented bar with hemivertebra are all types of vertebral anomalies that can contribute to the development of scoliosis.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 234

questions.text: A 45y old male came to the ER following a car accident with Quadriparesis, sphincter abnormalities, sensory level up to the upper border of the sternum, and a respiratory rate of 35/minutes. The lesion's most likely level is:
questions.solution:
• C4-C5 vertebrae are located in the cervical region of the spine and are responsible for innervation of the diaphragm, as well as the muscles of the shoulder and upper arm and also containing descending motor fibres innervating the lower limbs.
  • Injury at this level can cause quadriparesis, Bladder sphincter abnormalities, and a sensory level up to the upper border of the sternum, as well as respiratory distress due to involvement of the phrenic nerve.
 
  • Injury at the level of thoracic spine will produce paraparesis and not quadriparesis since the nerve fibers supplying upper limb muscles are derived from brachial plexus which receives its predominant contribution from cervical spinal nerves. 


Reference- Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma 10th Edition Page no 838

questions.text: Lift off test is conducted to test the function of:
questions.solution:

  • During the lift-off test, the patient is asked to place their hand behind their back with their palm facing outwards.
  • The examiner then applies resistance to the patient's hand as they attempt to lift it away from their back.
  • If the patient is unable to lift their hand or experiences pain during the test, it may indicate a subscapularis tear or dysfunction
.

questions.text: Which of these tumors causes hypoglycaemia as paraneoplastic syndrome?
questions.solution:

questions.text: For the past two years, a 17-year-old girl with acne has been taking a medication. She now displays blue-black nail coloration. The medicine that most likely caused the pigmentation mentioned above is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Minocycline
 
  • The above clinical scenario of melanonychia with the pigmentation of nail fold which is called the Hutchinson's sign. 
  • It is seen in subungual melanoma.
  • In benign nail pigmentation due to drugs (eg. minocycline) or injury (hematoma), the colour stays within the margins of the nail plate and doesn't extend to nail folds.




Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10243409/

questions.text: When a pregnant woman has an erythematous skin rash with several pus lakes, she should take:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Corticosteroids
 
  • Impetigo herpetiformis (pustular psoriasis of pregnancy) is the only definitive indication for systemic steroids.
  • Steroids can also be used for the control of acute symptoms like ARDS accompanying pustular psoriasis.
  • Steroids are contraindicated in all other forms of psoriasis as sudden withdrawal can trigger severe pustular or erythrodermic psoriasis. 
  • As most of the other medications are contraindicated in pregnancy, this is the only definitive indication for systemic steroids



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 115.8
