questions.text: The oral cavity of a young woman is filled with white lacy lesions, and her proximal nail fold has spread onto the nail bed. What possible diagnosis is there
questions.solution:
• Lichen planus is an inflammatory disorder affecting the skin and mucosal membranes. Nail involvement includes exaggeration of the longitudinal lines and linear depression.
  • It manifests as 6Ps pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar, papules, and plaques.
  • It also exhibits Wickham striae (thin white lacy lines on the lesion), and the Koebner phenomenon (new lesions at sites of skin trauma).
  • Mucosal involvement is common including mouth and tongue, rarely it can also be found on the anus and genitalia


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.1, 37.3

questions.text: An apparently healthy male appears with a white area on his tongue that looks like creamy curd. The most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Candidiasis
 
  • The given clinical scenario of white curdy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa in a patient is oral candidiasis. The drug that can be used for the treatment is clotrimazole.
  • Candida albicans is an opportunistic pathogen that causes candidiasis. It is yeast when part of the normal flora of mucous membranes but forms pseudo-hyphae and hyphae when it invades tissue.
  • They are not dimorphic. It forms germ tubes when incubated at 37 degrees Celsius. It is gram-positive and forms colonies of yeasts on Sabouraud's agar.
  • Acute pseudomembranous candidiasis: Sharply defined patch of creamy, crumbly, curd‐like, white pseudomembrane



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.59,32.56

questions.text: What are the walls of the CT scanner room coated with?
What is the biggest difference between X-rays and light wave
questions.solution:
X-Rays are a part of electromagnetic spectrum.
Electromagnetic spectrum includes the following energy components in increasing order of frequencies/energies- Radiofrequency ( Least frequency and energy )< Microwaves <Infrared <Visible Light <Ultraviolet < X-Rays < Gamma Rays ( Maximum frequency and energy )
All have same speed which is speed of light- 3x10*8 m/s and have same type of wave.
Note- Wavelength of X-Rays ranges between 0.01-10 nm and energy between 100Ev-100keV.


Reference: Walter & Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 19-20.

questions.text: Which of the following estimates the radiation dose to an individual organ within the radiation field the most accurately?
questions.solution:
Equivalent dose is a dose quantity H representing the stochastic health effects of low levels of ionizing radiation on the human body which represents the probability of radiation-induced cancer and genetic damage.
It is derived from the physical quantity absorbed dose, but also takes into account the biological effectiveness of the radiation, which is dependent on the radiation type and energy.
In the SI system of units, the unit of measure is the sievert (Sv).


Reference: Walter & Miller's Textbook of Radiotherapy, 7th edition, Page no 61.

questions.text: The following statement about CT scan features of adrenal adenoma is false:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Early enhancement with slow washout of contrast.
Adenomas typically have rapid contrast washout, whereas non-adenomas tend to wash out more slowly

Adrenal adenomas:
  • Most common adrenal lesion.
  • Often found incidentally during abdominal imaging for other reasons. 
  • In a setting of known current or previous malignancy, it is important to distinguish an adrenal adenoma adrenal metastases or other adrenal malignancies.
  • CT is usually the modality which identifies an adrenal mass. 
  • Since ~ 70% of adrenal adenomas contain significant amount of intracellular fat ( appear hypoattenuating/black on NCCT ), density evaluation of an adrenal lesion is highly sensitive and specific-Option B

Option A is a true statement. Calcification is rare in adrenal adenomas.
Option D is a true statement for it contains regular margins.

  • It is excreted primarily by glomerular filtration. Hence, it is the agent of choice for estimation of glomerular filtration rate to determine renal function. Below is the picture showing DTPA scan

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has been worried about his wife having an affair with his employer for the past two months. He believes that his friend is participating from abroad and offering technical assistance. He believes that others criticise him. Despite the efforts of his friends to persuade him, he is not at all persuaded. He is otherwise healthy; he doesn't exhibit any abnormal behaviour or thought disorders. The following is the likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: PERSISTENT DELUSION DISORDER
The given clinical vignette describes a condition called OTHELLO SYNDROME or Delusion of Jealousy. (Very frequently tested in exams)
A few important points, terms and syndromes to remember about Delusion:-
  • Timeline- More than or equal to 1 month
  • It’s a fixed, firm and false belief.
  • Apart from that particular delusion all order fields of life and functioning remains unaffected. ( VVV IMP)
  • Most common delusion - Delusion of Persecution
  • FOLIE A DEUX - Shared delusion where a person develops delusion after staying around a person having delusion.
  • DECLEREMBAUT SYNDROME - Erotomania [Imp clinical scenario frequently tested - The person generally a woman feels that the celebrity or a person of higher social profile loves her.]
  • OTHELLO SYNDROME
  • COTARD SYNDROME - Nihilistic Delusion-[Imp clinical scenario frequently tested- The person feels that his intestines are rotting and the world is ending.]
  • EKBOM SYNDROME – Delusional Parasitosis – Person constantly feels that he is infested with parasites.
  • CAPGRAS - FAMILY SEEMS LIKE STRANGER
  • FREGOLI- STRANGER SEEMS LIKE FAMILY
[CAPGRAS- FREGOLI: TRICK TO REMEMBER - A person cannot recognize his family members once they start wearing caps - CAPGRAS]


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 334.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is suffering from depression, palpitations, appetite loss, and insomnia. No complaints of helplessness or suicidal ideation have been made, and there is no prior evidence of any triggering event. In other areas of her life, she is remarkably successful. Her social life and work activities are both going about normally. What is the likely diagnosis in this situation
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario describes a condition called MIXED ANXIETY AND DEPRESSION.
  • By ruling out the different options, option (2) seems the best possible answer in this case.
  • Option (1) GAD- This case doesn’t describe GAD or Generalized Anxiety Disorder as it has been clearly mentioned in the question that all other areas of her life are fine and all her activities are normal. On the contrary, in GAD a person always feels anxious irrespective of time and place.
  • Option (3) Adjustment Disorder - It has been clearly mentioned that her social life and work activities are normal thereby ruling out this option.
  • Option (4) Mild depression - It doesn’t fulfill the basic criteria of BECK’S COGNITIVE TRIAD OF DEPRESSION which includes hopelessness, helplessness, and worthlessness.
  • Option(2) Mixed Anxiety Depression - It’s a condition where the person experiences symptoms of both anxiety and depression ( as described in this question)


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 415, 416.

questions.text: The following is not done in behavior therapy to increase a behavior:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Punishment. Punishment always decreases a behavior irrespective of the fact that stimulus is added or removed. To understand this concept better it’s necessary to understand CONDITIONING.
 
  • Conditioning in Psychology is a form of learning that can be of 2 types: I) CLASSICAL II) OPERANT
  • CLASSICAL CONDITIONING: It’s a form of learning in which a natural response is elicited in response to a conditioned stimulus that was previously presented with an unconditioned stimulus. This usually elicits an Involuntary response. Eg: Pavlov experiment
  • OPERANT CONDITIONING: Learning in which a particular action is elicited because it produces a punishment or reward. This usually elicits Voluntary responses. Operant conditioning works via Reinforcement or Punishment
  1. REINFORCEMENT – Can be POSITIVE (Response is followed by desired reward eg. Petrol given if driven for 100km without an accident) or NEGATIVE (Response is followed by removal of aversive stimulus eg. beeping sound removed onputting seatbelt). Reinforcement seeks to increase behavior. In both examples - the stimulus(prize/removing beeping sound) is done to increase the behavior of safe driving.
  2. PUNISHMENT – Done to decrease a behavior. Can be POSITIVE (Unpleasant stimulus given on undesired behavior eg. Fine on overspeeding) or NEGATIVE (Removal of pleasant stimulus on undesired behavior eg. Driving license/car taken away-inability to drive on overspeeding). Punishment seeks to decrease a behavior - in both scenarios -punishment is given to decrease overspeeding.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 877-882.

questions.text: The following is not part of the cognitive behavior change technique:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: CONSOLIDATION
 
  • The following question is based on the TRANSTHEORITICAL MODEL OF CHANGE.
  • This theory emphasizes the fact that the behavioural change of an individual occurs through 6 stages:
  1. PRE-CONTEMPLATION - The person denies problems and their consequences
  2. CONTEMPLATION - The person acknowledges problem but is unwilling to change
  3. PREPARATION - Committed to and planning for behaviour change
  4. ACTION - Executes plan and demonstrates a change in behaviour
  5. MAINTENANCE - new behaviours are integrated in lifestyle
  6. RELAPSE -Regression to prior behaviour. It doesn’t occur frequently.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 623.

questions.text: Two days ago, a 60-year-old man underwent heart bypass surgery. He now started to forget things and struggled to remember his family members' names and phone numbers and was agitated. Stayed awake all night only to sleep in day. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical vignette (sudden onset agitation/forgetting things/family members post surgery/hospitalization/sleep-wake issues) describes a condition called Delirium.
  • Delirium is often characterized by a sudden onset of confusion, disorientation, memory problems, and changes in behavior, such as agitation or restlessness.
  • In this case, the patient's recent heart bypass surgery is a risk factor for developing delirium. Other risk factors include older age, pre-existing cognitive impairment, and certain medications.
  • Depression and Alzheimer's disease are not the most likely causes of the patient's symptoms because they typically have a more gradual onset and are not typically associated with sudden changes in behavior.
Delirium Dementia
Onset Sudden Incidious
Conciousness Impaired normal
Course Fluctuating Progressive


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 697-701.

questions.text: Alcohol paranoia is linked to:
questions.solution:
• Alcoholic paranoia is an alcohol-induced psychotic disorder
  • It is characterized by delusions (mostly of persecution/jealousy/reference) Eg. a drunkard husband having the delusion that his wife is having an extramarital affair.
  • Auditory hallucinations may also be seen occasionally

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 337.

questions.text: Autistic disorder is not characterized by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: VISUAL IMPAIRMENT

A few important points to remember about AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS are:-
  • They are Pervasive disorders.
  • They are characterised by impairment in social interaction and communication, delay in developing and understanding peer relationships, reduced eye contact, delayed development of speech, fixated interest, and persistent preoccupation with parts of object.
  • Ambidextrous, no association with dermatoglyphics, precocious skills, mental retardation seen in 2/3 of patients. However they generally don’t have impaired cognition.{ A few one liners frequently given as stems in  MCQ questions}
 
  • This spectrum includes a number of conditions like AUTISM, RETT, ASPERGER, and HELLER.
  • AUTISM – Mental retardation isn’t present in all cases.
  • RETT SYNDROME – X linked dominant condition. MECP2 gene mutation. Seen in girls, abnormal language development, and mental retardation, regression of milestones, and normal head circumference at birth. [ V IMP TOPIC FREQUENTLY TESTED ]
  • ASPERGER SYNDROME – Common in boys.
  • HELLER SYNDROME – Common in boys. Mental retardation present, poor language development, regression of milestones and normal head circumference at birth. [ IN SHORT – SIMILAR TO RETT SYNDROME BUT COMMONLY FOUND IN BOYS]
  •  The following is a table with the most important features of each of the conditions which fall under AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS.

 


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1156.

questions.text: Select the option that is not a cognitive error/dysfunction.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 4. THOUGHT BLOCK

The various components of Cognitive dysfunctions are:-
  • Catastrophic thinking,
  • Mind reading,
  • Personalisation,
  • Magnification,
  • Minimisation,
  • Overgeneralisation,
  • Blaming,
  • Emotional Reasoning ,
  • Arbitrarily jumping to conclusions ,
  • Polarised thinking (All or none thinking) ,
  • Mental filter
  • Disqualifying the positive.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 875.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man and his wife arrive. He believes that he has been a sinner his entire life. He is really depressed and has thought about suicide, but he hasn't figured out how to do it. Additionally, he had sessions scheduled with a spiritual guru. His wife does not agree with him that he has lived a religious life. Anything to the contrary is not what he wants to hear. What will you do with him
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Antipsychotic + Antidepressant

The given clinical vignette describes Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic features.
  • Psychotic features are characterized by guilt occurring in the context of major depressive episode as described in the given question.
  • Treatment: - Antidepressants with Atypical Antipsychotics [A very close similarity to this condition is seen in schizoaffective disorder which is characterized by symptoms of both Schizophrenia and mood disorders.
  • However, patient must have exclusive 14 days of psychotic features without mania / depression]. Here the patient has suicidal ideation which cannot be cured by cognitive behavioral therapy alone. To do so first he needs to be stable with his thoughts.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 360.

questions.text: The following lymph nodes get lymphatic drainage from the spongy urethra:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Deep inguinal nodes 
 
  • The spongy urethra, also known as the penile urethra, is part of the male urethra that runs within the penis.
  • It is lined with stratified columnar epithelium and receives lymphatic drainage from the deep inguinal nodes.
  • The deep inguinal nodes are located along the femoral vein in the femoral canal and receive lymphatic drainage from the spongy urethra, the glans penis, the penile skin, and the scrotum.

  



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1283

questions.text: The following conditions have deficient branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
Maple syrup urine disease is a disorder of branched chain amino acids valine, leucine and isoleucine which occurs due to deficiency of the enzyme branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase. Results in accumulation of branched chain keto acids leading to Fatal ketoacidosis Mental Retardation Increased alpha keto acids in blood Characteristic maple syrup odor of urine Treatment- Diet lacking in branched chain amino acids.

Hartnup disease is a neutral amino acid transporter defect that leads to urinary excretion of amino acids.

Alkaptonuria is cause deposition black alkapton bodies in pinna, cartilages, sclera called oochronosis. 

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews Biochemistry, 5th edition, Page no 272.
